A good friend of our family, age 60, has been sober for about a year. He was hospitalized recently for a non-alcohol related illness. In addition, he stopped taking his anti-depressants. He was released two days ago and is drinking again. Does anyone know how long it takes the body to become physically dependent on alcohol making medically assisted detox necessary?

I?m a 24 year old alcoholic. I?m struggling right now. I?ve been hospitalized twice for withdrawal in 2021 and was in a detox treatment program during the middle of this past January. I love my family, my friends, and my job. No one is aware that I am struggling with alcohol addiction besides my parents and a close friend. But everytime I let them down, it hurts worse than the previous time. Even thinking about the horrible withdrawal symptoms, the shakes/sweating/vomiting, I still always want to turn back to drinking. I feel like I like myself as a person more when I?m intoxicated. I feel so much more confident and happy. I feel like I?m a better person?until the constant drinking catches up with me and my body rejects everything besides the alcohol. My issue is that I still want to be drunk, lol even knowing the fact that I know I need to stop, I know I?m only hurting myself, and I know that things will get much worse if I continue to drink. But why is it so hard even after suffering through all the consequences? Sorry for venting, I?ve never posted on this topic before, but I was hoping someone could give me some advice to deal with cravings or just tell me something they think might help me out.

My girlfriend is a very casual drinker. She gets drunk maybe one every 2 or 3 months and rarely ever has a drink outside of that, but she's also very small and has a low tolerance.

About 6 months ago she went out with a group of friends and got black out drunk. Her friends estimate she had between 10 and 20 drinks and we're surprised she didn't have alcohol poisoning that night.

Ever since then, anytime she gets drunk or high (Marijuana) she experiences tingling in her hands and feet and they go numb. Usually this lasts for a day and then wears off, but something different is happening.

We got high a few nights ago (VERY small amount of Marijuana. We rarely drink or smoke) and the numbness is way worse. She is relatively numb and experiencing the tingling you get when your arm or foot falls asleep, but across her entire body. We're on day 3 now and she says it's getting way worse. Yesterday it was just hands and feet. Now it's everywhere.

Everything we've read online makes it sound like neuropathy, but we can't figure out how it would have happened. She only experiences it when she gets drunk or high.

Is alcoholic neuropathy something that happens over time? Or could her one night of extreme drunkenness have caused this?

i found out my mom was an alcoholic last may. she?s been my best friend my entire life. recently though, she is distant and goes days without responding to me. since last may, she has gone to AA almost every night. last month, she ended up in detox which the doctor said was probably a cry for help. now she is in an extensive outpatient program which has lasted for around two weeks now. she went radio silence on me this weekend (my dad told me she just had the stomach flu) but she just responded that she had actually drank and is now very sick. i feel like i am the only one in my family who is scared and wants to support her. my dad usually gets angry at her/doesn?t want the whole family to know because he is embarrassed. i?m pretty angry he lied to me about her drinking. anyways, i guess i am mostly looking for some reassurance that she can beat this. she WANTS to get better. but despite being in AA and an extensive outpatient program, she continues to drink.

So, I have been drinking pretty heavily for the last couple of years. I took a month off at the beginning of 2021. My withdrawals were worse than I expected. After that month ended, I went right back at it.?? Fast forward to this past week. I decided that, instead of going cold turkey, I would taper off to one drink a day for a week or so. Today marks day 5. The first three days, I was pleasantly surprised that I didn't feel badly. I went to the gym. Didn't feel super anxious. No dizziness/sweaty nights/yadda yadda. Yesterday, I felt dizzy, lots of head pressure, body soreness. I took my temp and it was 100.7. I don't have a fever today, but I have NO appetite and I still feel slightly dizzy and off. Could this be withdrawals? Maybe I just happened to get the flu or something right as I was starting my path to sobriety? It's very frustrating.

I?m 23 and have had a drinking problem since I was 18. Although I did well in college, I spent most of my days drinking alone in my room. This stemmed from the fact that I felt like I couldn?t relate to the people around me. Regardless, I?ve been out of college for almost a year now, and it keeps getting worse. I alternate between binges and bouts of sobriety. Over the past year for instance, I did a month sober, two months sober, and then another month sober. In between this I was on a binge the rest of the time. Every time I become sober, a ?friend? (I have a lot of bad influences in my life) convinces me that it will be okay to drink again, despite me describing to them countless times how much of a negative impact alcohol has had on my life. This one night out always turns into me two months later not being able to go to sleep unless I drink 7 or 8 beers. In the past I?ve always reached a low point which motivated me enough to stop, albeit with really intense anxiety and confusion for a couple of days, but it?s only getting harder and harder each time. I can just see myself really going off the deep end unless I quit forever.

I only drink at night time, and on my current binge I?ve consumed around 8 beers every night for the past three weeks (I?ve drank a 12 pack the last three nights though). I need to figure my life out and this is the age to do it. The drinking has been getting in the way big time, and I know I absolutely need to stop if I don?t want to end up a complete mess later in life. I just can?t handle alcohol. I have a few questions for you.

How much of a risk do I have for serious withdrawals requiring medical attention? (I?ve only been drinking for three weeks on this binge and was sober for a month before it started, but the horror stories online scare the living daylights out of me)

What do you recommend I do to prevent myself from convincing myself I can drink and relapsing again? (I can never make it more than a month or two)

What should I do about my friends (who are also alcoholics but won?t admit it to themselves)?

I wish I was never friends with this individual
Ok to make a long story short when I was 23 I lost my best friend and sister to cancer. I struggled with life for a bit. I met a friend S who was a few years older than me but had no job. I tried to be a good friend and took her to several job interviews. My friend S had a problem with alcohol. I was in the middle of grieving so for awhile I turned to hard core partying with her. I had never been a badass and was always a rule follower. Quickly I realized I turned into a massive AH. Fortunately the turning point was when I received a job offer in the legal field. My lifestyle had to stop. I turned my life around and stopped binge drinking. My friend S ended up getting into drugs and even stole my prescription meds. That was the final straw of our friendship. Over the years, S has tried to get me to be friends with her again. I refused. In my hometown where S lives we have a community page. I have moved away. The other night I posted about a very bad accident. Underneath the comments section was S?s mom saying I needed to quit judging people and that I?m on a high horse. She then went on to say I have ruined her daughters life. I have not had any contact with S besides these FB messages that occur every couple of years. I also after the comment was made I received a message from her mom saying to quit being an asshole. Ofcourse this got people in the community talking so I responded to S mom that I was friends with her daughter in 2010, don?t have a high horse and am not perfect. Then blocked S mom and made sure daughter was blocked as well. People in the community have sided with me saying that S mom was wrong for bringing that up on a community page. I feel for S and I wish she would get help. Since friendship ended she gotten her 8th DUI and she even a charge of endangering children. I?m a different person now. After getting these messages it made me want to move even farther away from my hometown and old life.

I am in my early twenties, and I would consider myself a heavy drinker. I am a bit worried about the health of my liver, so I was wondering if I should get a blood test to check my liver? I don't think there are any obvious signs that my liver is damaged, but better safe than sorry.

I?ve been an alcoholic for over ten years now but I toned it down a lot. In my early 20?s I was blacked out all day and drunk at work. These days I go to work sober and drink after and from morning to night on the weekends. Last night I drank a lot more than normal after my girlfriend went to bed. Today I was sober and we went with my girlfriends parents on a day trip. While we were walking to a restaurant I just randomly passed out and fell on rocks and really hurt myself. The pain was so bad I kept falling over even after I came to. I?m just trying to understand what?s going on. I?ve never done anything like this before.

I discovered my girlfriend has been cheating on me and it sent me into quite an ugly relapse where I can't really remember the last two weeks. Anyway I've had a noise complaint after a drunken shouting war on the phone with her. Either way I'm confident I'll stay sober now because I can't take another year of this

I hope that everyone is doing OK... I was thinking about my triggers to use... it's emotions... I don't deal well with the tough stuff on an interpersonal level... I think that the pandemic has amplified it too... loneliness, isolation... stuff like that. I live alone and work from home so I am alone alone. I also don't have a good relationship with my family. I'm working on it.. Determined to go back to AA meetings right away, on wait lists to see a therapist, fixing some meds with my psyh doc, so.. I'm taking care of business.

I start drinking in the evening and most of the times it ends okay. I wake up in the morning still feeling like a looser, but I at least didn?t down an entire bottle of vodka.

But any time I get on the phone with someone at night (which is why I try not to talk to people at night) or when my sibling comes to stay the night, I just end up taking it to an extreme level. Always, always end up blacked out and even before I really wake up I know immediately I?ve fucked up so badly, feeling the crushing effects of hangover and extreme anxiety about what stupid shit I even said or did. It?s literally the worst feeling ever. Ever ever. Yet I still keep doing this shit.

If I talk to people during the day I end up shaking, sweating, feeling so much anxiety. So a lot of times I just never answer my phone and everyone always complains that I?m ?the hardest person to get in touch with?. Well what they don?t know is I avoid them because it stresses me out and I don?t know why. I have a lot of resentment towards cell phones. I don?t want one anymore. I?m so sick and tired of people expecting that I should answer just because they called and they are getting mad. I?m sick of being tied to this device. I wish I could go back to the days of landlines where it was not expected people would answer and we just had answering machines for that reason. People didn?t generally get pissed when they didn?t get in touch with you. Now days it?s like because I have a cell phone people think I?m looking at my phone 24/7 and ignoring their call on purpose.

That?s not true I?ve tried to make an effort to be off my phone and sometimes I lose track of where my phone is even at. But yes, there are times I see someone calls and I don?t answer it because I?m not in the mindset to talk.

Anyways, the time will come where I see someone calling in the evening and I know I?ve not responded enough and I feel pressured to answer so I do. I answer or call them back and I start drinking right away. And then no matter if the conversation is good or bad, I keep knocking back the shots. To an extreme degree that I don?t do when I?m not talking to people. It?s like I can?t have a conversation and be normal, or not stressed, unless I?m drinking. But then I take it too far.

So then when I wake up the next day, the entire day I?m cringing and freaking out about the stuff I remember, and panicking about what I possibly did that I don?t remember, hiding from my phone, logging out of my social media because I?m terrified about what stupid shit I?ve said and I can?t even face it. I can?t even stomach to see notifications. It?s crazy.

Like why?. How is it I can go through that all day and then when 7pm hits, I?m back to drinking again. Thinking I can somehow only have one or two drinks when that?s never going to happen.

I really, really hate myself. It won?t be long before everyone I?ve ever known and a bunch of people I don?t know hate me just as much. Obviously there?s no good answer here other than getting clean which I feel is absolutely impossible at this point. By the end of the day I?m so extremely stressed out and feeling pain in my body it feels impossible not to drink to make it all stop. But I also get so pissed off at myself that I can go through so much torment all day about what I did while drinking then just go and do it again and again and again. So stupid.

I was fine today, and then I read a post about someone else who was struggling (and it wasn't even in this sub, it was in the AskReddit sub and the topic wasn't even about alcohol) and I just lost control. I haven't had anything yet, but I am having a REALLY hard time not blowing the rest of this day to shit. My hearts beating fast I'm like fighting myself. Just, the struggle is real. I'm trying to forgive myself in advance and I just can't.

?m 31. Been an alcoholic for 13 years. I?ve decided to quit. I am currently 6 days in.

I feel I?ve gotten over any initial withdrawal symptoms. However my issue at the moment is the ritual nature of the habit. I used to have a very set regime. I?d be at work 8-7 most days. I?d never drink at work or whilst working from home during working hours. However I would then drink on the way home and for the rest of the evening. Life was literally split in two.

I?m finding that period between leaving work and getting home/ eating dinner the hardest. I?m just getting the constant feeling of wanting a beer. I haven?t succumbed yet but just wondering if there are any tips to take your mind off it. I?ve so far avoided the gym as I used to basically drink on the way home after. However once I feel I can trust myself more I may return.

In my mind I have the reference of quitting smoking. I quit a few years ago. I found then that the initial pain of quitting was far worse than what I?ve experienced with alcohol. However after 2-3 weeks that nagging feeling of habit and wanting that cigarette eventually went away and I just naturally stopped thinking about it.

So I?m wondering 1. Any tips on how to get over the pangs and 2. Does it go away over time. Realise that?s a somewhat facetious way to express this but I can only frame it in the context of my experience with smoking!

He's been an alcoholic for as long as I can remember. Last spring it got really bad and my family and I put him in rehab under Section 35 (Massachusetts). I thought that might've been the last straw and he'd stop drinking. There was hope for a short time.

But nothing has changed. He won't go to AA meetings and he won't see a therapist. He says constantly that he wants to stop drinking that he's "tired of living like this." But he won't put in the work.

I'm just so done and tired. Part of me wants to keep pushing him to get help. The other part of me wants to cut my losses and get out of his life. For good. Never talk to him again. I'm just really depressed over this and I don't know what to do.

First, this group has helped a ton in the first few weeks since quitting drinking so thank you! I'm over 3 weeks now but the only thing that is strange is my loss of appetite. I eat maybe once a day unless I force myself. I'm just not hungry. Has anyone else experienced this?

First of all, this sub looks like an amazing group of people. I love when Reddit is a community of friends and supporters for what's more or less strangers on the Internet.
My story
Been a casual drinker all my adult life, but since COVID I find I have 2-4 drinks every day. Lately, that's turned into sipping an oz of rum when I start work at 6-7 am because I feel withdrawl in my head. I'll have another couple oz in the afternoon; sometimes it doesn't abate the feeling.
I do not binge drink ever, rarely get drunk and silly -- just 2-4 drinks, 365 days a year. Maybe I used to drink to mask depression, but right now I drink for the same reason smokers take cig breaks.

broke up year ago with soulmate shit happens alcohol is my only friend even im sober for week i feel empty inside guess what half liter of vodka of beer my mom hate me for that and shes most beautiful person u can ever wish have as mom my siblings lost hope in me they think i take drugs even i had weed one time in my life...i have dreams with ex thoughts with her and just random mood swings that i cant handle im already dead just hope i can give as my friends love me happiness to their life for some short time...i hope im gonna make it but i dont think so...and that come from guy from army, football and many shit i dont care who iam anymore

So now I'm on 2 strait weeks of doing the exact same thing. I'm off Thursday and Friday. Last week I started drinking Wednesday night and drank three nights in a row. Saturday came, I was late for work and I suffered for a little bit before asking to go home. So fast forward I recovered pretty quickly but was in massive pain for the first night. Now this week, I do that exact same thing but stopped yesterday because I couldn't drink because I was just throwing it back up. I don't understand how two days of heavy drinking can do this to me. Anxiety is bad, chills and sweats and I have to suffer through work. I don't have the option to not work. I have a cushy sales job so I can just lay low most the day. My challenge is not to yap to my coworkers to keep my anxiety down.

I'm done. I listened to an AA meeting last night for the first time. I didn't stay the whole time but I'm getting on a program. I cant keep my life together like this. My issue is I cycle. I drink for a few days, sober up and rinse cycle repeat. It's destroying my mental health. I'm not having any bad thoughts, I just want to feel better. I poured all the booze out when I went for the poweraid.

I'm at 30 days today and honestly it has been a walk in the park. I used to drink a lot every day, I was up to ca. 135 drinks a week, which is 100 drinks a week more than at least one diagnostic guideline for alcoholism that I was given. I did decrease my daily amount before quitting completely, though, but I was still getting fully drunk every day before quitting.

I've had almost no cravings, I've lost noticable weight (I've also worked out a lot), I've saved hundreds of dollars, and I feel way better now that I'm not constantly a little bit nauseated. Just in case anyone is thinking about quitting or taking a break but isn't sure they can do it, it doesn't have to be torture. I've been pleasantly surprised by how easy it has been. I had like one rough day, the rest have been kinda boring, but not very hard.

I think it has been easier for me because I haven't committed to never touching alcohol again for the rest of my life. When I think about doing that, I kinda panic, so I benefit from a more casual attitude. Booze wasn't causing any huge problems for me, other than overall shitty health and empy wallet (but I have very few expenses so that wasn't really an issue), I just decided to take a substantial break (at least 3 months) because my relationship with drinking had become unhealthy. I expect to get to a point where I can have a healthy relationship with drinking again. However, if I find out that I'm incapable of that, it's nice to know that I can do sobriety without suffering. Also I still smoke weed, which helps.

Alright so this just happened like 30 min ago, it's 01:25am, im just playing with the cat on the floor but also half in the hallway, my mom gets out of her room to go to the bathroom. So my room is right after the bathroom and she comes up to me crouched down, playing with the cat and says let me go to the bathroom, I ask her what? She says let me go to the bathroom, move out of the way and she starts pulling on my wardrobe dresser thing, she pulls off her nail and then gets angry at me kind of yelling are you kidding me? And my dad is right in the next room and he woke up to that and obviously gonna confront my mom in the morning about that which I'm still a little scared about because just now I can hear him muttering stupid cow, why is she screaming shit like that.. makes me really anxious and scared. Anyway I tell her the bathroom is over there and then try to lead her towards it, she pulls back at first but then goes in, uses the toilet and comes back out to my room to the exact spot again and says let me in the bathroom again. I tell her you already used it she then gets angry again and starts yelling, goes into her room and now is probably sleeping. I guess I kinda needed to type this out because I got really scared I haven't seen her like that, oh it was her birthday today too and I think she only drank couple of beers and now my dad is going to make her feel bad in the morning too which im anxious about, they've had lots of fights in the past. Sorry if this is rule breaking, I just needed to tell this to someone.

I've cut my alcohol intake in half since we met (approximately 50 units a week now,) I end up in an argument with her every time I drink to excess, and I hate myself for it, because it's usually my fault.
What's annoying me today is that she's threatening to leave me over a bottle of whiskey I'd supposedly "hidden" by putting it somewhere in plain sight and she just hadn't noticed it until it was empty.
I tried to explain that I bought it yesterday when we were both at the store, but she didn't see me buy it so she doesn't believe me.

I have a family member in their mid twenties that really struggles with alcohol and I'm rapidly losing patience. He's already gone through one side of his family and now it feels like he's making his way through ours. The cycle of starting over with him every few months is so frustrating! The thanks yous he does offer up seem so hollow when he puts everyone through so much crap every few months, like a transparent effort to tell people what they want to hear/butter them up for his next ask. I try to remember that this is a disease, I swallow my anger and annoyance and try to offer up support and encouragement, especially because everyone else is getting to the end of their ropes, but I'm thinking of joining them at the end of my own. Sometimes I feel like I'm lying when I say "love you" back at the end of a phone call. How do I find a new reserve of patience to deal with him?

Honestly it started off as me just saying I was an alcoholic as a joke. Always talking about its in my blood an I can out drink anyone. Well thats how it started then my cousin would get me booze an I started at like 15 mostly to impress this person I was seeing who was just cheating on the person they were with. I would drink on occasioan but I never really cared mostly because im an introvert an id just stay at home all the time. Then my dad moved in for a month...I though we would connect an it would turn things around, but I just saw how horrible he really is. Picking him up while he was stinking drunk an my best friend was in the car really did a number on me. Later that year My godfather died from liver an kidney failure...alcohol didnt help but I got the moonshine and so many other bottles. Eventually moved out an turned 21 so I could buy my own went to a few parties and would drink like a fish no hangovers just fun...my depression started to get worse after I moved to the big city. Im such a mommas boy that it was hard being that far away and I was having issues with relationships. I was in such a bad place that when my own birthday came up I drank anything in sight did whatever drugs I could pay for an just really hoped I wouldnt wake up. The company I worked for went under.I lost my job which I ended up using some of the money for cases of booze or weed. I then moved in with my now ex. Thought it would be better but my drinking increased I was now drinking almost every night. Not to get messed up but just a buzz. Well along with my cheating and other issues including drinking we broke up an I continued dating someone else. They called me out on my drinking but I would brush it off. Saying that I have it under control an that im not an alcoholic but we would go to events an id bring booze an when we were at their place id bring booze. I kept saying that this is because I didnt have weed to smoke but once I got weed I still wanted a drink. Eventually with the issues I was already causing we decided it would be better if I didnt drink anymore because it was causing problems an cheating. This past November I started having health problems some bleeding an I got some work done well I was feeling fine an then in January when I hit my 1 year of sobriety I felt great...until the health problems came back...an I thought well if im just gonna keep feeling this pain anyway i should just go back to drinking atleast that way I'll die faster an nobody will have to worry. This caused a breakup to happen an I never take my breakup with them well. Ive been drowning myself every weekend since then. At this point idk if i even want the help I hate rehab with a passion an never wanna admit that I have a problem. Honestly I just want the booze to kill me. My meds arent working an I do not have the will to keep going. I dont care about myself enough to stop the only reason I ever stopped was for others because I kept thinking they would hate that I went out this way but after a while I just assumed everyone hates me so its easier this way

So I worded the title that way on purpose, I was referencing Kevin from the Office?s line about few words doing the trick. Anyway, I?ve noticed that alcohol makes me think better thoughts when I?m tipsy or drunk, if that makes sense. Like throughout the day, I usually feel a sort of anger or dissatisfaction with my social life if that makes sense because I feel like my friends are too needy sometimes and I have to avoid them. But when I?m drunk I view this as a positive and realize how good friends they actually are for dealing with my shit sometimes so I should be less angry towards them. This is not to say I ever show them that I?m annoyed, I put up a good front cuz I know good friends are hard to come by and I feel bad for feeling the way I do. But fuck is it hard to feel anything but negative feelings towards them when I?m sober, like I wish I could just get away from everyone and everything for a few months. Idk if this is even making sense cuz I?m tipsy while writing this but I just feel shitty cuz it feels like I have a better moral compass when I?m drunk than when I?m not LOL also, alcoholism does run in my family. My grandpa (RIP) was an alcoholic, so was my stepdad and one of my moms sisters (aunt) is an alcoholic.

So I?m just gonna rant about my day and see if anybody has helpful insight. Spent my day taking care of the kids (2) till I saw my parents. The new news is that my grandmother went to visit a family member and after the trip my grandmother is now in the ICU because she is confused and has a low O2 saturation. To make this super complicated, She was visiting the Uncle that raped me and a cousin as kids. That uncle is currently a vegetable because?. (I have no idea because family knows never to talk to me about him) I heard the news about what was going on and I immediately left my parents house and drank. Got home and my wife knew I was drinking and tells me to call my therapist. I agree but I hate talking about my issues and addiction. After writing this I realize I need some encouragement for me to make calls and appointments.

I 35f have been drinking a bottle and a half of wine every night for the past 10 years. My problems started in 2009 when i went through a really rough patch with a narc ex, i lost every bit of self esteem and i couldnt sleep at night, i tried to sort myself out i stopped drinking and docs gave me zopiclone to help me sleep for a short while, ive suffered with anxiety since i was 15 but my parents never believed or helped me overcome this. Im now at a stage where im back drinking every night to beable to sleep also i need to have a few drinks before work and during to keep my anxiety attacks away. I hate this so much i hate alcohol i hate feeling like this, i constantly feel tired im just so embarrassed, im spending so much money out my pay check every month on alcohol and taxis to get me to work cos i cant walk there anymore cos im too anxious that i may aswelll not work. I just feel too scared of withdrawals and too ashamed to visit and confess to a doctor what ive done to myself, where do i begin,

This is a throw away account. I?m scared, I?m 19 years old and feel like I?m slowly digging the hole for myself. I know I?m not a ?true? alcoholic, but I know that I don?t remember the last time I went two full days without being drunk. My family has a history of alcoholism, I keep telling myself to stop. I imagine myself denying a drink that is offered to me. I imagine myself passing the liquor store and not buying booze. I imagine myself opening the fridge, seeing those beers, and not grabbing a couple. But this imagination isn?t my reality and I fucking hate it. I can feel my mental health declining, I know it?s from the alcohol, but once I see the drink, I deny it?s negative effects on me. My brain replays my memories of being drunk and it feeelss gooooood, I fall into my own mental persuasions; ?just one,? I tell myself. But that one turns into any amount that makes me not able to walk in a straight line, talk without a slur, or worse.

5 years in total but the last 2 have been hell. I've been lied to, cheated on, kicked to the fucking curb and made homeless. She has said over and over again she'll change. My girlfriend saved my ass when I was a miserable hopeless drunk. Now the tables are turned. Big violent episode last night. Idk. I begged her to stop drinking for the first time. Finger crossed I guess.

I hope this is an appropriate place to discuss this. I'm an alcoholic who's been sober from alcohol for about 2-3ish years (had a couple relapses but I can't remember the last time I craved a drink). I'm also a big fan of YouTube content, and I've been seeing more and more creators I like to watch accepting sponsorships from Bright Cellars. They are basically a subscription box for wine. I think they send you three bottles a month. While they haven't really made me want to order anything, it concerns me as an alcoholic that they could make other alcoholics want to. When I was first trying to get sober the ads for alcohol on tv were a huge temptation to just relapse. I'm not sure if these ad reads have the same kind of impact of an advert on tv, but it just makes me wonder if anyone is having trouble with these sponsorships on YouTube. Does anyone have thoughts on this?

kinda unsure about making this post but feel like i need to do it anyway. i?ve struggled with drinking in the past but managed to sort myself out a bit. it only lasted a few months until i got covid and my anxiety spiked. since then i?ve been drinking 3/4 beers a night to help with it along with binge drinking on the weekends. lately i?ve felt myself slipping a lot more with my drinking and always have to hair the dog due to crippling anxiety the next day after heavy drinking or i?ll get heavy anxiety if i don?t drink a beer. this has been going on for about a month and i know that the alcohol isn?t helping me and is just making me worse but it helps in the moment. drinking 3/4 beers every night has been going on for jusy over a month and due to having struggled with it in the past i don?t want to spiral again.

Male, late 30s, high performer, finance exec.

Throughout my adult life I have probably drank too much, and mostly alone.

My typical pattern for quite a while would be Sat - Tuesday sober, Wednesday drink a 6 pack, Thursday sober, Friday drink a 6 pack or bottle of wine or little bit more.

Last couple of years it's probably escalated somewhat, to where 90% of days I would have 2 - 6 beers, and at least once a week have 7 - 12 beers or equivalent.

It is clearly alcohol abuse by any reasonable standard, and generally if I have 1 or 2 drinks, I will tip over a point where I want to have 5 or 6 or maybe even 10, basically drinking until I become sleepy and pass out.

I already know the obvious answer: Yes. Am i ashamed? I don?t know.

I am so disgusted with myself at times it is hard to cope, and so again i turn to beer. I know alcoholism is a disease and it runs in my family so i try not to judge myself too harshly, but i have gotten to a point i have no pride in.

I started drinking when i was 14 years old. I would go to a bar n? grill with my parents and they would get me a glass of cheap champagne if i had been good lately. I thought that was just fun.

Then it turned into me driving my parents? dunk friends home when i had never driven a car before. When i had also had a drink or two. Then that turned to my parents yelling at me for my drinking when they were the ones who, almost, encouraged it.

Just started my first full time job post graduation of University. I?ve been here for 4 days. Today, the company had a little bit of a party to celebrate after work some achievements they made. Everyone was drinking. The kitchen fridge is filled with beer. One of the cabinets is filled with different kinds of liquor. I was the only one not drinking (I drank water). I thought starting work would be good for me and keep me busy, just to find out my work has alcohol readily available in the kitchen. This is a disaster. Both my bosses were drinking as well.

As of lately I?ve been loosing the motivation to stay sober. I feel like it?s not helping me anymore. I feel empty inside all the time. All I feel is angry and empty. I don?t feel happy, sad, hurt, or anything besides angry. I could at least process emotions drunk. Now I can?t. I?ve lost my job, and with it my entire life?s career goals, I?ve been struggling in life, and I?m generally unhappy with the way things have turned out for me. I don?t think it is worth it anymore. I just need some help before I go buy a bottle.

in the rare moments of sobriety i'm intensely anxious about the health consequences of this lifestyle. and what's really funny is that drinking is my only coping mechanism for that anxiety. i wake up every day and immediately check my skin color in the mirror for signs of jaundice. i'm always feeling around my abdomen to see if something feels off. i keep going to the urgent care up the road asking them for tests to reassure me that i'm not dying. and i'm not yet, but the numbers are getting worse every time. i used to think maybe i'd be motivated to stop once i saw evidence of bodily harm but now i've crossed the point and it hasn't slowed me down at all. i'm scared dude, i am NOT the kind of person who doesn't fear death, i fucking dread it

not sure if this is the right place to post this but here I go. My girlfriend of about a year has been diagnosed with alcohol use disorder. She insists she doesn?t have a problem. Oftentimes when we go out to dinner she will drink to the point she is drunk. After about two spirits she is noticeably drunk. However what is most concerning to me is how she uses alcohol to cope. If she has a bad day at work , or an argument with her roommates , or even a disagreement between us she will drink excessively. Am I wrong to be concerned about where this is headed? I have been surrounded by alcoholics my entire life and can?t help but to see her heading down this road.

I've just woken up from a black out from, I don't think I did anything very bad but it's very stressful, I suffer from BPD and when I get manic I over drink, I'm sorry if this is not the correct place for this I just feel incredibly remorseful for my actions and needed to tell someone, thanks for reading this.
So I just got banned from crippling alcoholism. I said bad things and the white women with affluenza got mad. But I'm going to a meeting tomorrow night. Things are looking up I think.

I am sober 17 months and like many alcoholics there is a little bit of the brain that wonders if I could drink in moderation.

Well, yesterday, I was at hospital for a colonoscopy and instead of sedation opted for gas and air (which was far more comfortable than when I have had sedation). I took the first breaths of the gas and started to feel a buzz. It felt like a drunk feeling.

My alcoholic brain immediately took over and chased it. I was huffing the gas as hard as I could and as fast as I could. Not because I needed it at all. Purely to get more buzz. The more I got, the more I wanted to the extent as I was very disappointed when it was all over.

Lesson learned, I know this is exactly what I would do if I drank.

Over the years I have DRASTICALLY reduced my drinking. I am very proud of what I accomplished. However, I still get occasional cravings that I would like to eliminate.

Since reducing my drinking, I was able to get healthier and reduce my tolerance. In the past, I used to be in a constant state of being drunk and hungover, and both my body and mind saw it as normal. Now that I am healthier, I REALLY 'feel' the effects of drinking. It takes less alcohol to get me drunk, The hangovers are 100x worse and the aftereffects last 2-3 days!

My problem is that I like to drink in the evening/night and also have a drink with dinner. I find that alcohol compliments food very well. I want to cut this habit completely out. What are some alternatives?

Yes, alternatives. I know some people aren't going to agree with that part but I would rather do something else than deal with a hangover at work because I was an idiot the night before.

I?m an alcoholic. I know I am, I haven?t always wanted to admit it, but I know I am. I won?t lie, I?ve been drinking tonight as I write this. But the question of ?what do you do for fun living a sober lifestyle?? has always been the biggest thing for me never committing to staying sober.

Drinking has become a staple in my social life, but I can?t drink like the people around me do. All of my friends drink because they can handle their shit. They can go out and get shitty on a Saturday night once a month and have a beer or two after work every now and then. I can?t.

If I drink, I have to get drunk. And if I don?t drink, I can?t sleep. I drink almost every night, and drink excessively at that. I drink just to fall asleep. I don?t even enjoy drinking most of the time. The only time I do enjoy it is when I go out to the bars or to a party with my friends. I wish I could be like them because I know that?s the only time they drink. But when I?m not with them I?m at home drinking by myself every night.

I wish I could cut out the drinking in between the nights out and that be that, but I can?t. I?ve tried many many times. I?ve been thinking about going to rehab lately and committing to quitting all together. But what do you do when you stop? It?s so hard to imagine a social life without alcohol. Is that just the addiction talking?

Side note: I also kind of feel stupid. I know there a lot of people out there that feel the need to be drunk 24/7 and I?m just a guy who drinks nearly every night to sleep. But I do feel like alcohol is actively fucking up my life.

My dad has always spent his evenings drinking shitty beer in the garage watching a tiny tv for as long as I can remember (I?m 27 now), and then promptly falls asleep in the recliner or on the toilet. He never goes to bars to get drunk nor gets aggressive so he doesn?t view his drinking as a problem. He recently retired and it?s only gotten worse in my eyes, and any phone call after 7pm typically isn?t remembered the next day or is just slurred words.
How can I get through to him that I?m worried about him but mostly tired of dealing with drunk dad? Sober dad is great and charismatic, which makes seeing the opposite drunk dad harder to deal with emotionally. He is still married to my mom who doesn?t drink and she has always given him hell for the drinking but he never toned it down based on her issues with it from what I saw.
Alll the advice on the internet I?ve found is for people who drink hard liquor and like sneak it in their pocket and drink even at events and stuff, or get aggressive. My dads case seems mild but is emotionally still frustrating and he definitely doesn?t consider it alcoholism as he says he can go without beer, and has before.

My wife and I are both functioning alcoholics however I can tell that my ability to function is deteriorating and I am terrified I am going to lose my job because of it. We have an incredible daughter who is doing so well and I absolutely do not want her growing up with alcoholics for parents. I think I am ready to stop however I feel this way every morning and by 4:00pm I am all set to crack open a beer. My wife and I try to do things to minimize our harm like taking a day or two off each week but never more than that. Every time we talk about our drinking it becomes a very stressful conversation and usually ends up in an argument. I get the sense that my wife is not at all ready to slow things down and I am afraid to even bring up the idea of getting help to stop. I feel like I am at a breaking point and I do not know what to do.

First off, I?m 20 and in college, so alcohol has been a big part of my life, but not to the point where it?s hurt me. I didn?t miss class, get sick or go broke. Spending 2-3 nights getting pretty drunk. But I?ve spent times drinking by myself at night, not getting plastered but to have a buzz. It was relaxing and let me destress and fall asleep easier. I enjoyed the feeling. As I?ve gotten home and drank (a lot less and less often) I?ve noticed I pretty much only drink by myself or while In contact with someone digitally, and the desire to get full on drunk and feel the effects more has gotten stronger. This has gotten worse after quitting nicotine 2 weeks ago. I also get the feeling of ?man I could go for a beer? despite not wanting to make a habit of drinking. I can go without drinking, but I enjoy myself more when I have some drinks at night. All in all I can?t tell if I have a problem, am getting close to one, how much quitting nicotine is effecting me, or if I?m overreacting.

I quit dabbing hardcore about a week ago cause i got my wisdom teeth out and for the past week every day ive been taking 3-5 shots of hard liquor i was wondering if I should be worried ive never really binge drinked before but i also have a gastric bypass surgery [stomach shrinking surgery] so im not supposed to be drinking to much because it affects me more since my stomach is the size if a apricot I have been dealing with stomach pain from severe gastritis and all 4 wisdom teeth out at the same time i wake up soaking wet in sweat and shivering because of it I always have to change cloths and grab a new blanket i just started a new job and im not gonna drink at work but i wish cause i get the worst back spasms after being on my feet for more then 3 hours im nervous for the future.

Should I go to the hospital? I don't have a job or insurance and I feel absolutely terrible every day UNLESS I drink, right now I haven't eaten in 3 days. Have horrible tension and tremors. I went 10 hours and had horrible anxiety so I gave in. I drank water and a sports drink and threw them both up. Im trying to taper and my mind and body are freaking out, as I have cut back. Should I go to the ER? I have a consultation with a doctor tomorrow, should I be straight up honest on the first meeting? Is this normal?

I haven't posted here because I was ashamed of myself.

I stopped drinking for around 3 months previously. Then I convinced myself that I was "better". Hid behind all sorts of justifications.

"It helps me relax/It is a treat/I enjoy it"

Now it has been around 8 months. I'm drinking 4-6 pints a day. I wake up everyday feeling like hell. My kidneys feel tender. I struggle to make it through the day because I am largely trapped in a life I don't want. Work a job I don't mind but don't feel passionate about. My son I love but I feel now he is getting older, he wants to spend less time with me and more time with friends online. I struggle to arrange childcare because my support network has fallen apart due to a Narcissistic father who I had to cut out of my life.

Some days I feel content for brief moments. Other times I feel absolute despair. Heartache. Feel so alone bar my son and work colleagues, who are the closest things I have to friends. It feels like I'm just treading water until death takes me but I don't want to die. I can't die or my son is alone. I've tried a few nights to stop and the withdrawal is really bad. I feel nauseous. Sweat. Feel tired. I can't go to work like this. I tried and it was tough.

This is going to be long and I'm sorry. I'm only 23 and I don't really drink at all,but i know alcoholism is hard to beat. I've seen it make so many of my friends and family suffer. I swore to myself I would never stay willingly in a situation that subjected me to the same kinds of things I faced before with other alcoholics, but I've been with a (27y/o) guy for almost 2 years now who a few months back picked it up hard. We had a rocky start to our relationship, and I stayed under the impression he was bettering himself and we would grow. He didn't drink hardly ever then. I fell for him very very fast and I wasn't ready to let him go. I wanted to see him through. Things were better for a month or 2 before he started drinking. We had a lot going on for so many reasons and I didn't really hold it against him, as long as it didn't seem like he was abusing it. Fast forward to a year later, and I've been punched, choked to black out, things thrown at me, gaslight heavily, numerous broken down doors and holes in walls, etc. Everything I swore I wouldn't let back in my life..x10.

Due to campral I've been able to stay a month sober. It hasn't been easy and I'm astonished I've gotten here. I'm happier than I've been in a long time, I'm achieving goals.. things are amazing. If you think you can't make it, don't give up. It's taken me a million times to reach 30 days.

I won't drink with you today.

I believe I had a strong alcohol dependency in sophomore year of high school (I was 15). For context, I was extremely depressed and didn?t have too many friends.

After the first time I got drunk, I got totally obsessed with the feeling. I would count down the days until I knew I would drink again and always tried to drink whenever alcohol was available. On that note, it wasn?t available often: I could go a month without drinking purely because I didn?t have the means to get it. Is it still a dependency/addiction? I didn?t have so many drinks a day but if I had the ability to get it myself and didn?t have to rely on others I think I would?ve been on a much different path.

A few nights ago I downed an entire 12 pack of Trulys and a few hours later ended up vomiting it all up, along with a little puddle of blood about the size of my fist. That's never happened to me before, and I've drank more than that in more condensed time periods. Maybe covid has something to do with it too, but I'm guessing it's more about the prolonged drinking. I'm making an appointment to see a doctor about what happened today after work but I'm terrified for so many reasons to admit that I might have a problem with drinking, so much so that I can't really bring myself to admit or even type that I'm

It feels really good. Though the want for a drink is constantly lingering. I?ve picked up crocheting and I find it quite enjoyable. Helps my hands stay busy and my mind stay focused. Hoping for more sober days.

My husband of 20 years is an alcoholic. A functioning alcoholic. He hides his alcohol in our home but I have always been able to tell by the subtle change in his voice when he drinks. He's an amazing father, worker, friend, and most of all - husband ...that I was lucky enough to marry when we were 17 & 18 years old, but, he is slowly killing himself. His parents are alcoholics...he hates that about them. His Dad has early onset dementia. His Dad is in his 60s & a functioning "healthy" alcoholic. He was an avid runner, rode trails on his bike - hell his heart grew its own bypass around his widow maker clogged artery that they found when he eventually did have a heart attack & can no longer drive anywhere. His Mom is a mean & spiteful drunk who lashes out - it used to be mostly at him but we have cut them out from our lives.

Most here know, drinking is not your problem, but it is the "solution" to your problem...

To those easily triggered, I ask you not to read on and know I truly hope you are finding the support and help you need, but if you read on, I also hope you see this as a story to maybe learn with, or gain some insight into the mind of someone on the outside of this terrible affliction, and that some of us DO understand you.

My brother passed away this past Thursday morning. He received a liver transplant ~5 years ago that was needed due to drinking. He sobered up just long enough to be eligible, got his transplant, and stayed sober for about a year after.

At the beginning of his journey, none of us understood the mental struggles he was battling that led him to drinking. After his transplant, we started understanding this and tried whatever it was we could to support him through it.

He was very quiet about what he was going through emotionally and mentally, so to the outside many just thought he was a hopeless drunk.

I beg each and everyone of you, many of you struggle with this horrible addiction due to the same reason my brother did, but without being fully open and honest with those who support you, you will further isolate yourself trying to protect those around you. It is also important to make sure you do whatever it is you can to break through whatever "therapy wall" you have that scares you from seeking the right help. I pray no one has to go through what my brother did in the end. Dying from alcohol is a tough thing to see.

Mental health is a very foreign thing for some to see and understand if they themselves do not suffer from it as well. Seek the support you need. There ARE those who will do anything and everything they can for you. You ARE wanted and loved. I am not angry with whatever caused him to struggle, and led to his life ending. I am not angry with my brother for not being more open with me. Being angry will do absolutely nothing now, so I chose to love everything left by him, and I chose to do whatever I can for others who are also going through this.

Mods, I am not active here, and was not even a subscriber unfortunately, so if this goes against any rules, I apologize, but I felt this a step for me to go through and if it even helps one person here, I'm doing my part.

I am open to any comments and questions, whether good or bad, and even constructive criticisms you may have for me.

I?ve always gotten addicted to things easily. I never leave the house. I don?t talk to anyone. I?m always anxious. Tonight I was craving beer like crazy which would mean 5 nights of drinking in the last week. I was going to sneak it and then I realised that if I?m trying to hide it, it?s a problem. I really like the feeling of alcohol. The ritual of drinking a beer just feels so good. This is a problem. It?s taking all my willpower to not give in.

Not sure wether to ask this here or anywhere else? Recently for about a couple of months I?ve noticed that my hangovers are getting considerably worse, compared to the amount of drinks I?ve had. It doesn?t seem like it gets worse gradually, but more as if there?s been a turning point. I?ve been reading some things about this phenomenon, however, I turned 20 not too long ago, which would be quite young for this to happen. Right?

I began drinking to cope with a toxic work situation just before the pandemic. Work was life then, and so it was emotionally devastating. Then with the pandemic, like most people, things went upside down. Starting in April 2020 I've lost a family member to one thing or another about every 6 months or so. I've gotten to a point where a bottle of wine doesn't touch it.

I'm on day five of not drinking with the intention of not consuming alcohol again. I've been lucky to not have many physical manifestations of withdrawal, but the desire is there. For a couple of days I've had massive mood swings, including irrational anger that is new to me along with a deep, deep depression. I know several things contribute to the depressive episode, but in the back of my mind is the little voice that upending not drinking is the quickest relief.

I have a friend ? 32(m) ? same age as me who currently is an alcoholic; has been for years really. For context, my mother was also an alcoholic and sadly died in September 2020.

I?ve recently had to stop seeing this friend as our friendship had become so toxic. Honestly, I could write a series on the amount of BS that want on ? and it went on and on.

I think my main issues was, I was obsessing about his drinking. I tried to help, I tried to change him. It was totally fruitless; and we constantly got into heated arguments about it in the final few months.

Truth be told I think this issue served as some sort of proxy for my grief: if I could save this person then it would go some way to make me feel better about not being able to save my mother. And to this idea, I just latched on. I was prepared to do anything and I did a lot of things, went out of my way etc to help this person when seemingly it was all in vain. It took up a lot of my time and energy.

Now that I?ve distanced myself I realise how big an effect this has had on me, my wife and our marriage. I don?t know if it was tunnel vision or sheer pigheadedness etc but I was so determined to help it meant shifting my focus away from my family, my work and myself in general.

I was totally deluded.

This realisation has hit me hard. Was I so deluded I couldn?t see the damage this disease was having on me and my family? It?s as if someone has flipped a switch and suddenly I can see how messed up everything was/is; how I refused to listen to reason; and how I?ve let a lot of people down.

I had good intentions, I was trying to do the right thing. It?s weird though, it?s as if me not properly grieving created some sort of codependency that did a lot of damage. Now my eyes are open and I wish I could put everything back but naturally things aren?t that simple. I?ve hurt my wife a lot.

I don?t know where im going with this. I guess it would be good to read if anyone else has faced similar issues with and addiction/ obsession to someone else?s addiction? Because I also most feel broken by it to the point I?ll need to put myself back together.

Time to find new hobbies to do while feeling this way. Reading a book or riding my bike.

I have so many ideas, but I just can't implement them.

In recovery (had some slip ups recently after two years) I work right now, my boyfriend doesn't. I have trouble not wanting to drink on my days off. My boyfriend is letting me stay at his family's home rent free right now and the last time I got him to clean was after weeks of fighting and me drinking(also huge cause for the fight) . This guy. THIS GUY goes "well I guess you could do a small load or two in the dishwasher out there.

I didn't even think about drinking now its like my body is craving taking a few shots, putting in headphones, and cleaning it all while zoning everything out and enjoying being drunk rather than sitting here in stewing in the fact that he AND HIS FAMILY don't clean anything.

The last few days off I've drank and ots resulted in him shouting at me at the top of his lungs. Because I drank not because I acted a fool or anything when I did.

I?ve been drinking heavily for 6 days straight and I woke up today feeling shaky. I also drank some G-fuel yesterday and this morning. Me (26F) and my fianc (27M) have been together since we were in school (ages 18 and 19). We have pretty much grown up together, school sweethearts, blah blah blah. We own a house together and recently got engaged in May 2021. Lots of fun and exciting life events happening at the moment, and things are pretty good.

However, I am starting to notice that alcohol may be starting to become an issue for my fianc. For background, both his parents are alcoholics and have a strained relationship with drink. My fianc doesn?t drink that regularly but it seems to be very linked with social situations. He won?t drink much during the week (maybe one or two beers in total) and he will often have a couple on the weekend. However, if we go to a pub, to a friends place, or have people over to ours, he will drink to excess. Easily 8-10 pints of beer (24-30 units).

When he drinks this amount, his personality changes and generally not that fun to be around. He is not physically or emotionally abusive in any way, but his behaviour changes, if that makes sense? He is more erratic and his ability to behave in a restrained manner is impaired. He will spill his drink all down him and all over the table/floor, and generally embarrasses himself. He will wake up the next morning and not remember parts of the evening behind a certain point. Meanwhile, the rest of our friends are only drinking a maximum of 3-4 pints and just having a good time. My fianc does have a higher tolerance to alcohol than some so it takes him a few extra drinks to feel drunk.

Me on the otherhand, I don?t drink unless it is a special occasion. Even then I will have a maximum of two drinks, and I don?t even enjoy it. I?m happy being designated driver, and don?t have a problem being around people drinking as long as it?s civilised.

A few days ago we had one of our very close friends (27M) over for dinner and a chat. He?s just come back from a long trip and we were looking forward to catching up. We ate and they shared a few drinks between them, but my fianc kept drinking. I lost count of how many beers he had in the end but it was easily 8+ of very strong (6% ABV) cans. It was coming to the end of the evening and we were sat at the breakfast bar in the kitchen. He thought it would be funny to grab onto my feet and tickle me whilst sat on a bar stool. Initially it was funny but when I told him to stop as I was sliding off my seat, he didn?t and I slipped and fell to my knees on the hard floor. I got some pretty funky bruises. Instead of helping me up he just chuckled and told me to get up. Our friend was very taken aback and said he would make his exit as he felt uncomfortable. He helped me up and then went on his way.

We went to bed and I when I spoke to his later the following evening after I got home from work, he said he couldn?t remember any of what happened. He was very upset and I know he would never have done it on purpose. We spoke about how I felt about the situation and whether he thought it was an issue. He said it was becoming increasingly hard for him to only have a few drinks and then stop, like there is no off switch. He mentioned feels miserable and depressed at the moment due to work and is worried that it?s becoming a coping mechanism. He doesn?t want to become like his parents.

He had been trying to better himself recently, eating healthier, going to the gym, limiting himself to a few drinks a week. Then it?s like he?s lost the off switch. Our friend has also spoken to him about his concerns and is worried about him.

I guess my question is, what can I do to support him? He says he wants to reduce his drinking, or stop altogether. It?s tricky for me as alcohol is not something I enjoy so I?m finding it very hard to understand how he is feeling.

My clean date is 10/13/2021, best decision of my life and I?m grateful every day I did. Recently I had COVID, and while I had it, I did drink a significant amount more NyQuil than I was supposed to (not anything that would be able to get me drunk, probably just an extra dose or 2 at once because I was feeling like shit). It was only because I was feeling like absolute dogshit and wanted to pass out as quick as possible, not at all for the alcohol. I didn?t know it had alcohol (the kind i have always had was non alcoholic) until the second night of taking it, and I still took it but only the amount I was supposed to. I?ve worked really hard on staying sober and I don?t want this to count against me but I did technically have alcohol and the first night I took more than I was supposed to, alcohol or not.

And the doctors arent in very often. :( Keep getting switched between ativan and diazepam.

I'm too sick to keep track myself. But it's like... sometimes I say a low number about how bad the pain is. Then get nothing.

Then I say its.worse and they.say I am overexagerating. I just font know how to answer to get proper care...

Doc said to bring me diazepam instantly then the nurses ignored me for 2.hours until I was seeing and hearing things screaming hyperventilating with ears covered.

I?m going to be taking the at home route for detoxing (I get it, people always say you need to go to a clinic), and want advice from people who have taken a similar route. And just to be clear: No, I will not consider AA or rehab, so I won?t even read your response if it starts that way.

A little background: Been a daily drinker for almost 10 years (ages: 24-34). Started as a few drinks a night daily drinker to now around a pint to pint and a half of vodka a day drinker. I have never had the shakes and always spread my drinks out to avoid a hangover. I also don?t enjoy being drunk, so I avoid it. I just enjoy the buzz stimulation I get (almost like motivation).

Well, I?ve realized that my tolerance has increased so much that alarm bells are going off. I also don?t really enjoy drinking anymore. It feels more like a crutch than it is an enjoyable past time. I told my wife I think I have a drinking problem. She was super supportive, and now I am looking at either the tapering route or the cold turkey route.

Luckily, I have Xanax and Propranolol to help with withdrawal symptoms. If you know of any other medications/supplements, please let me know.

My POV for tapering: It will reduce the possibility of DT?s and seizures but it?s a slower process.

My POV for cold turkey: It will be quicker but increase the risk for DT?s and seizures. I?ve never even had the shakes but I don?t know if that?s an indicator of anything.

However my blood work has been getting progressively worse year on year. Now my BP is very high and my blood potassium levels are high. I have tapered down on the alcohol my doc gave some benzos if things get tough. My question is has anyone experienced this and their kidneys got better. BTW Surprisingly my liver enzymes are within limits.

So I have been on a bender. And I finally have to stop. I drank wine pretty heavily. I?m about 14 hours since my last drink. And the anxiety is real. I can?t sleep I have taken a Valium. But the anxiety is still present. How much longer am I going to go through this.

I had been drinking for 40 years, the last 10 quite heavily (i.e., 2-5 bottles of wine a night).

Like many of us, I was hiding most of the drinking and terrified of stopping due to all of the horror stories surrounding AWS. Inpatient detox and rehab were off the table due to $$, but I found an outpatient clinic that required an intake appt, 5 - 15 min daily check-ins and provided a round of benzos (Librium or Valium) all for about $500. You could probably also do this with a sympathetic MD.

So, I got all ready. Bought a blood pressure cuff and a pulse/oxygen meter at the drug store. Told my wife I?d been drinking too much and was stopping and asked her to ?keep tabs on me? For a few days. But I didn?t mention all of the possible horror stories. She was thrilled.

ZERO HOUR: three bottles of my finest wines remaining. Gave the rest of my collection t

My mum is 54. She has a successful career and is married. However, she drinks 10 drinks plus nearly every night of the week. Multiple nights she will be so wasted that my dad will have to 'put her to bed' at 8pm because she can barely talk and cant keep her eyes open any longer. She becomes so embarrassing and can often start fights when she is drunk - But of course everything is my fault and I'm the evil one if I try to bring up that she may have a problem with drinking or should stop after a couple of drinks.

My dad is a pretty big drinker, so its a massive aspect of their relationship - but recently my mums drinking has been taken to far and we both cant say anything because she will just lash out at us. She becomes extremely defensive and will come back with viscous remarks about why something you've done is worse then her drinking etc. I just don't get why she cant have a couple of drinks? Why does she need to get absolutely plastered every single night. Its not a joke anymore, its seriously upsetting, distressing and frustrating. These drinking habits have been going on since I was young. And my brother and I (21 and 19 years old) growing up and still now) would both dread "champagne nights" because we knew she would end up obliterated.

She gets up every morning and exercises early, goes to work, has good blood tests and lives a good life. So in her head she thinks theres no problem.

But there is right? Alcohol is causing problems in her family/social relationships, weight loss goals and sleep schedule - among other things.

I just dont know where to go from here - I cant wait to move out of my family home again, because every night I dread when happy hour starts for them at 5pm. I just retreat to my room for the rest of the night because seeing my mum/parents so wasted for no reasons makes me feel almost ill.

I really want to help her and my dad into a better space, but I really don't know where to begin with how previous conversations on the topic have gone.

Last summer my uncle in law came to stay with us after his wife kicked him out and filed for divorce. She did it because he lost his job due to drinking and almost died from it. He told her he quit and she constantly found him drinking secretly. His first night with us he was wasted. We never said he had to be sober but said we would like him to try to be. He never drank in front of us but we could tell he was always drunk. We use to drink every single night and stopped before he came to us so there wasn't any temptation. A few months go by and he is still jobless, stays at the house everyday, all day but swears he is sober and constantly getting interviews. I had a REALLY bad week at work and warned him that I would be drinking but would hide in my room. Came home to a bottle of vodka and wine on the counter. Vodka for me, wine for the guys. Ok? The next day there was a bottle of whiskey and most the vodka gone. It quickly became normal for all of us to drink openly together. A couple of weeks later we tell him we are going back to not drinking and he should too after I saw him get a cup of just vodka at 6am. "Tomato less bloody mary" he told me. He didn't drink for 1 whole day and his body went into shock. He was throwing up hard all day and when he went to drive to the store he had a seizure and was hospitalized for a week. When he came out we said rehab or we kick him out. Amazingly he went to rehab for 5 weeks, came back and was a quiet/stoic man for a little while. Took his meds, went to his daily AA meetings and seemed to be doing well. Until recently. He's back to being obviously drunk again while bragging about how amazing he is at AA and how they made him a lead. We didn't have proof until we started to watch the camera in our living room (that he was aware of!). We saw him leave the house, come back with a brown bag and go straight to his room. Then came out with an empty bottle of vodka and took it out to the recycling. My husband went out there, grabbed the bottle and confronted him, leaving out the part where we saw him from the camera. He denied it and said he was cleaning and found it which was a lie. We said we weren't going to kick him out but he needed to get his shit together. Since then we have seen him do the same thing 4 more times. Bring a brown bag straight to his room, bring out a now wrapped up bottle and take it to his car instead. (We checked the recycling/garbage and it doesn't exist) We know he is still drinking and know he is being extra sneaky about it. Just don't know how to approach him about it. "Hey we started watching you through the camera you know about and aren't dumb?" Losing his job, wife, house and almost dying twice has not stopped him. Rehab, therapy, AA and us confronting him did nothing since he just lies about it. Do we just act like we don't know, continue on with our lives and pray his moves out soon? Have an intervention?

Not sure if this is the place for this or not, if not I apologize. But I felt it time to get this out some way, some how. And ?I guess? is a total crock of shit. I know I do and I?m stuck in it. I have a great career, a wonderful wife and son, talks of having another, and I am a drunk. I function pretty flawlessly hammering bourbon and barely sleeping. Alcoholism and addiction runs deep in my family. My father gave it up years ago and has found religion in its place - no chance of going there for me - and I have become a master of hiding it in plain sight, either with clever excuses or well placed anecdotes to explain a slip up, both to others and to myself. I can?t survive much longer doing this. I?m 43 and aware of what this is doing to my body and it is unsustainable. But I am also trapped in a cycle I have created for myself in that I cannot seek help, at least not openly. I am looked to as the rock for an unstable family situation, both immediate and extended. I cannot show weakness.

But in the past two years I have had lots of blackouts. It?s almost uncontrollable. I am in a long term relationship that is constantly tested when I drink. There have been bad trust issues caused by alcohol but he has stayed around and pushed through. He?s given me endless chances and I?ve told him that it won?t happen again, but it does. I drink too much just one time and it causes me to lie, treat him poorly or just be a mess. I can?t lose him and I don?t know what to do. I?m 23 and I don?t even go out with my friends anymore because of it. It?s just the social norm and I have no idea how to move forward. I have gone months without alcohol, tried to slowly re-introduce but it always ends up with just one bad night.

January 22,2008 called 911 and felt like I was going to die. Had been on a 30+ day bender and couldn't stop drinking. Ended up in the ER detoxing for 7+ hours. It was sitting in this room with monitors on my chest and iv's in me that I had hit a bottom at 43 years old. I had been drinking since I was 14 . At 14 I drank about 1/2 pint of Golden Grain and felt like I was in an opium den. This is where it all began for me. I drank like normal teenage males drank until I hit about 21 years old and hit the bar scene. I always worked and held a job, but the disease started flipping on me around age 40. I no longer controlled my drinking, it was controlling me now. And the amounts were going through the roof and death was near for me I could tell. Jan. 22 , 2008 was it for me. I made a decision I was an alcoholic and I could never drink again .On jan 23rd 2008 I started my journey. 5114 days later I don't feel like drinking. I don't want to go backwards. I don't want to suffer anymore. I battle through life sober now. Each year gets easier. If you have any questions or are struggling today please feel free to PM me.

I'm just curious if anyone has experienced anything like this, the first time I got sober I don't rember this happening, but then again that was a 4 day detox in the hospital.

Anyway I'm like 2.5 days sober and the last couple nights this strange thing has been happening. For one, this is like, probably stay up too long tired (but it's nice to feel that real tired behind the eyes feeling again, not drink till passout, if that makes sense) and I will be drifting off to sleep and just as I'm like transitioning into dream land the volume of the dream will suddenly spike super loud and jolt me awake. This will happen a few times in a row. It's sorta messing up sleep but I already knew sleep wasn't going to go back to normal in just a couple days and despite this I still feel more rested.

I used to go out and drink with friends, but now I just want to be alone and get plastered. I hate my life. I have attempted suicide twice while drunk and ended up in an inpatient mental health facility one of those times. being in there gave me a sense of clarity I had never had before but, as soon as I got out, I went back into the same old cycles. now shit is getting worse and worse. but I still cant imagine my life without drinking. My dad started drinking shortly after his knee injury 7 years ago. At that time I was pretty young so I really didn't think much of it. He wasn't able to walk for at least five months after it so I can only imagine what he was going through at the time while being bedridden.

At first, all he did was cry when he was drunk. It was so loud I'd usually leave or stay in my room with music playing to drown it out. But as the years went by, he only got worse.

Gradually he became more vocal, saying what was on his mind that he usually kept to himself when sober. Especially things about my stepmother or me that should be kept to himself. Even then I didn't realize the gravity of how wrong that was. Not until I got up to my senior year of high school. That's when he would shout and cuss at us. Not physically violent but enough to scare us. And I had such a hard time understanding why he was like this and why he would be harmful towards us.

Now a few years after the pandemic I can't imagine how much worse he can get. He drinks and drives, mentally and verbally abuse me (recently come to terms with this), and drinks almost every day.

I'd like to say that I still love him, but it's hard not to resent and hate him at the same time. I feel guilty admitting that but I'm not sure how else to express my feelings about it either.

Nine years ago, an event happened in my mom?s life that caused her to go down an alcoholic spiral.

I?ve lived at home for 8.5 years of it. There were many nights of coming home to screaming, fighting, and overall abusive drunken behaviour. Things would get thrown, banter would last hours, and it would be constant.

There were also many nights of coming home to see her passed out drunk on the floor. Those nights were more bearable.

All of this constant fighting, hatred, and fear developed over time. I would find myself jumping every time I heard a noise downstairs, thinking she stumbled, fell or stomped her feet. I would be scared to make a noise after coming home, in case she is passed out and I could avoid being around her for the night.

Now it?s at the point where I never know if she?s drunk. She?s been drunk working from home, when she drives, and in most conversations it?s like talking to a child, even when she?s sober.

I?m starting to realize these traits manifesting in myself and I don?t know what to do. I just want to get away from everything. I?m so tired.

I (26M) got so drunk last weekend I fell over and broke a rib. Not the first time I?ve injured myself drunk, but never like this. I proceeded to get up and dance half naked on stage, with a broken rib. I brushed it off for a few days but after the pain got worse I took myself to hospital.

I?m housebound for the foreseeable future and it?s quite miserable. I?m on a low dose of codeine (prescribed) for the pain so I literally can?t drink, but this has given me a moment to think about my actions and how alcohol is ruining a lot.

I want to get fit, lose weight, be healthier, study more, and focus on what?s really important. It?s been my goal to improve my life, and I?ve been trying, but that next drink has always taken priority. ?Just tonight? turns into the next day, then the day after, which leads to 5 or 6 days in a row. I?ve lost myself in the process. I?ve taken breaks from drinking before, and God I love not being hungover, but I think ?just tonight? should be a daily mantra I apply to being sober from now on - every day.

I?m not worried about telling my friends I?m stopping drinking, but most of our plans revolve around it. I can stop drinking alone, but my worry is that a night out with my friends will trigger a binge or me drinking alone again. I have bipolar type 2 and when I?m hypomanic I tend to binge too. It?s always a balance.

If you?ve been in a similar situation, how did you do it? Are you able to get into a place where you can safely drink?

But I drink a lot. My go to at a liquor store after work is a couple shooters of vodka and at least 4 beers. This is on a light day.
