Consecutive Days off for me these days are just "well lets drink 1st thing in AM....you'll get drunk quickly....pass out....wake up....drink some more....pass out again." That has been my M.O. for a bit now. I think it gets worse in the winter since there is nothing else to do anyways.

Well, I woke up today after this pattern and of course I went ahead and grabbed me a beer. Chugged it and felt uneasy right after I did it. I never puke up alcohol but this was a rare time I actually did. I puked it up and then at the very end I puked up blood.

It was definitely an "oh shit" moment for me. I thought it might have been a fluke and just a one time thing but when i was brushing my teeth I went ahead and forced myself to puke and yep of course some coagulated blood came out.

Fuck. Theres part of me that really is scared and I think the alcohol numbs the other BS as well. Does this just seem like a stomach ulcer? I have no pain in stomach but i might be just numbing it completely out. IDK.

I'd much rather spend that money on the booze. It's so expensive nowadays (at least in my country), that it makes me pissed that sometimes I'd rather to spend it on something I actually enjoy. I mean, enjoy way more than eating.

So I talked to my husband when he woke up. He didn't remember anything but as I walked him through the events as I experienced them, he came to the same realization that I did. He knew he messed up and called our HMO about getting treatment that same day.

The doctor prescribed naltrexone and counseling. My husband says that with the pills after he has three drinks, he doesn't feel like drinking anymore. He can go the week without drinking, then isn't feeling the need to binge on the weekends.

It's still early but what I'm seeing so far is promising.

Basically my coworkers and I went to a going away party for someone who worked there. Everyone had a drink, not me. I drank diet coke and had to listen to their silliness and genuine happiness as I stared at my sobriety app under the table, counting the minutes. Four months and ten days.

Managed to maintain my fun loving personality and I got home okay, but damn do I have a headache.

Honestly it feels fucking impossible to escape alcohol references, whatever it is. Ads, friends and family drinking that of which I have zero control over because I currently live with. The only friends I have (those of which I have moved away from as to escape a city full of narcotics for my own good) all drink. Everywhere I look I see or hear alcohol it's nauseating.

What can I do to make this easier? I feel like I've tried everything.

I know I've pushed the limits for a while now. I don't have hangovers like we all complained about when we were young! I'm a spry 36-year-old that people always say looks much younger. (I guess good genes and I didn't smoke?) No idea, because I've destroyed my body the last 15 years. Nonetheless, I've become increasingly concerned as of the last few years. I attended an uncle's funeral and found out many skeletons of many people's closets and it pushed me to the limit. Has anyone felt so bad after pushing the limits for a few days that they then become red all over their body and out of breath for a couple days? Can't really walk right, shaking for a few days while still intaking like 10ish/night, horrific headache etc. for like a week straight? I mean I got the hot/cold sweats and tossing and turning, but I wasn't quitting. I was still at 10+/ night. Heart beating super fast might be the worst part. Honestly, it's not like it's the first time it's happened, but going through withdraws when I still was taking 10+ just so they didn't get worse. I realize it's not healthy. It's probably happened like 20 times over the last couple of years. I also work with doctors, so I feel like they all know, and I'm performing a circus act walking a tightrope. This last time was the worst.

I do know inflammation is no joke, it's linked to like 120 diseases, (the worst being cancer, diabetes, heart disease), and alcohol causes inflammation, so it's only an amount of time. I just wonder what all those symptoms mean. The kidney alone can cause pain basically anywhere. Are all my organs are mad? My body is slowly dying? Both? I also just stopped using birth control. But shooting pains everywhere mixed with feeling like I can't catch my breath is scary when I'm a normal weight for my height. I think I reach an alcohol induced level of amenia. I'm just scared of all of the pains. I mean, for the last 7 or 8 years I've been averaging about 15 to 20 shots a night, (I've got single digits for certain months spread throughout).

I mean, I guess I know the answers. . . I just need someone to talk to. I honestly think it's more than just an addiction. I think I'm unhappy, and it's not about myself. It's a general apathy about the world even though I'm the kindest soul to everyone. The world is a piece of shit and I realize I'm a tiny piece of sand in the ocean. So, I drink to ease the day when everything horrible is happening that everyone chooses to ignore and nothing is done about? Yes, I'm equating my drinking with the world's problems. Could I be much more attractive if I really tried? Yes. I have friends that, that's all they do and people think they're amazing for just being pretty. I guess that's all they care about. Could I have finished my masters? Yes. But, I looked into my career path and it's not necessarily going to help with pay or competition. Could I have succeeded further though? Most definitely. I know I squandered opportunities and left some soot on some bridges. I'm upset about that. Could I save my relationship? Yes. I might be able to. Can I save my body? No idea. I feel like it's probably bad news bears. I think my outside looks a million miles better than what's hiding on the inside, and I can feel it physically.

I was seeing this guy, let's call him L (25M) who was a recovering alchololic. I didn't know at first how serious it was and he was 6 months sober, but he said he was never doing that well before and it felt different than any other time he tried. He was actively doing everything right, in therapy, built himself a structure to stay sober. I thought it was okay. We became very intense but were open and honest and happy, very emotionally available and healthy at setting boundaries. He did tell me a month in that his alchololism was much worse than I had imagined before and then i started to wonder if he should even be dating since he didn't have a year. we had a serious conversation about it, talked to both our therapists, but since we seemed to be doing well, and he wasn't drinking and didn't think he would, we decided to take me going home for christmas as a tester. I thought we were doing well over the break in seeing eachother, and we were for a bit. But he apparently almost relapsed. He didn't leave his room for four days, two weeks after being apart. He didn't eat for 6 days, he lost a stone (14lbs), he had to stop himself from drinking by taking 2 hour showers, he told me he hurt himself which he never did, all to stop him from drinking. He said that he had built a structure to keep in going, but it wasn't strudy enough to handle the wobble of a new relationship. He was apparently doing well on the high of us being together, we were so happy and doing so well, but when I left he didn't pick himself back together or return to his coping mechanisms. We had to break up which is heartbreaking, we both feel so strongly about eachother. I normally don't feel like connections are even real but this seemed so rare. He wants us to try being friends but I don't know if I can do that for him with out it being complicated which would further jeapordise his recovery. I care about him so much and want to be there for him (there were other things contributing to his downward spiral, not just me) but I don't know how. Right now we are in limbo, going to talk again.

I just want advice, or words of encouragement. I just want to know what I need to do so he'll be okay - I'm heartbroken we can't be together and the timings off, and so is he, but I don't want him to jeaoprodise his health and recovery. I don't know how to be there for him without being a problem. It also makes me doubt if his feelings for me were genuine and could have been healthy and good at another time, or if they were just a type of high? He says he won't try dating at all after this (we were just supposed to be a causual hook up, he didn't intend for this to happen but then, we clicked) because this is one in a million to him, which makes it even harder because I think he's right. I guess I'm just sad and scared for him. I wanted to be able to be with him through any of his struggled, even if he did relapse I wanted to be able to support his recovery, but I didn't realise how much I was putting it in danger. If anyone has advice or words of wisdom, that would be so appreciated. I'm kind of at a loss, I want to see him in any way but I need to and will do what's best for him and his recovery.

I am 24 years old and I've just starting officially going out with a guy who is 28 years old. I'm a small woman who doesn't really drink so when we first went out and he drank 15-20 pints of beer in one night I was taken aback, but I didn't think too much about it because people sometimes do like to let themselves go as people like to say. However, every time we have gone out to different pubs he is always drinking at least 4 pints to my 1 pint. He works in a building society and earns a very good wage, but after he's finished work he goes to his local for a few beers and then he'll ring me (without sounding drunk at all, but I know he has a few beers because my friend works at the pub) and we'll go and watch a fillm at a cinema and then back to the local for a few beers and then I'll stay at his place (he has a 4-bedroom house and he has already let me have one of the rooms to myself). He never gets a hangover. He's up at 5am and gets himself sorted and then leaves to go to work.

I've stayed at his for a few days and every day he drank 3-4 litres of cider, about 8 cans of beer and some whisky or a couple of bottles of wine.

On a Friday he finishes early and I meet him in town and we go for something to eat and then we'll go to restuarants and pubs and then get a takeaway and go home. On the weekend he'll cook us something to eat, but he drinks a couple of bottles of wine by 3pm and then we'll go out.

He went to college and then university. He reads lots of books. He's a very educated man. He's also a very quiet man who never causes any trouble.

From what he has told me, his ex-girlfriend wasn't very nice to him and it hit him hard.

I get on very well with his mother and I work part-time so sometimes I meet up with her during the week and we go shopping or for a bite to eat.

I mentioned my concerns to my mother and she told me that I shouldn't worry as long as he treats me right and avoids drugs (her best friend died of a drug overdose). My father also used to go to the pub in the evenings and it never was a problem for my mother.

Should I mention anything to my new boyfriend?

Oh great. I've just got to this charming point in the proceedings where drinking actually makes you feel BETTER. I remember this, from last time. About 8 hours after I last drank (so basically your standard work day), I start to feel sick, and get the hiccups. If I persist, I start to feel like I'm going to vomit. If I still persist in my foolish foray into sobriety, I start vomiting. If that's not enough to push me back into a bottle, I then start vomiting blood. The tremors really kick in about then, along with the hallucinations, fever, hiccups and more vomiting blood. If I drink, though ... About 7 straight shots in short succession in, and my symptoms just go away. All I feel is pleasantly buzzed. I know I'm dying. Again. I know the symptoms, from the white shits to the seizures. It's been 7 years since I had to do this. I lived to see 30, my life improved. But now, here we are again, the only thing thing that makes me start to feel better is the one thing poisoning me. I think I'll go in for drug and alcohol counseling this time. Maybe there's help to be had there. This time though, I have good people in my life, who care if I live or die. Sending care out to all of us dealing with alcoholism right now. May you all be safe, recover, and be happy.

I?m 29, will be 30 in April. I got my blood work results. My RDW and alkaline phosphatase are both high. Looked them up and these are both related to alcoholism and liver damage? I also have a high A1C for my glucose check. I go for a follow up on Monday. I thought once I saw that I am actually damaging my body I?d feel more hardcore about quitting but I don?t and I?m super scared? I have sober days now. Like today. Then I fall off again and drinking during the middle of the day just to feel something. Why can?t I quit? :( It?s ruining my life and my body. I find it hard to just be with my mind and thoughts when sober. I get bored and then drink again and then regret it. It?s the insanity cycle.

Ive been drinking everyday since 15 , i am 22 now look like a diffent person when i stop drinking i dont get withdrawels but only cravings. and yes i have been drinking everyday for 7 years besides a month or two of intermitted breaking

It's the definition of insanity. I wake up, decide I'm going to get my act together, only to wind up blacked out by the end of the night. My actions have become progressively more regrettable as I become toxic to everyone unfortunate enough to care about me. I feel genuine remorse for the unpleasantness I inflict on others, but that isn't enough to stop me cracking open another can, and repeating the same behaviours. Gradually I've started to set lower and lower standards for my pathetic self, and I still fail to meet them every single time. I've been haemorrhaging friends and relationships for the last year, and their departure is certainly not met with kind words, quite the contrary. I'm a software developer and I'm less and less often able to keep up cognitively, if I continue I will not be able to keep this job, I will not be able to afford my rent and I WILL wind up on the streets. If that doesn't deter me, is there a force on this planet which will? I'm close to resigning to the fact I'll always be a drunk and there's nothing I can do about it.

I?ve been an alcoholic since I was about 20 years old. I am one month away from turning 28 and I have drank alcohol pretty much every day since I turned 20. I tend to go up and down in my consumption sometimes I?m cool with just drinking a 3-4 and calling it a night. Other times I?m drinking 8-12. I?m currently in like a 7-8 a night pattern which is like just a normal day for me.

I can?t really seem to cut down or stop, my fear of boredom sets in and I drink. I never usually drink during the day because I work except on some occasions where I?ve had some to get rid of my hangover. I don?t really exercise as much as I used to I used to be very active and eat healthy along with drinking every day to try to counter act it.

I?ve noticed I?ve been getting heart palpitations or flutters the past week and rosacea from the heavy drinking lately. The rosacea will usually go away if I cut back.

I?ve been sober for the past 2 months, recently got sick with a flu and my mother bought me some herbal syrup, and after 2 days of taking it I read on the bottle that it contains 10% of ethanol and I kind of got mad at it, I know it may sound irrational because it was an unintentional act, but still?I know it may sound stupid?I don?t know, I think i?m just frustrated

I bought a liver function test for $179 the other day. I don't know how I'll deal with results.

My liver function tests were abnormal pre-COVID but could be explained by I'm a bit overweight. I've drank every night, no need to go into the office, since then like my life depends upon it. I got freaked out when I saw a bit of bright red in my stool.

It's not fair to my parents and my sister's family. They don't deserve to explain to their kids how their uncle died at 39 from alcoholism.

The scary thing is that I don't know if I can quit. The self-hatred is so intense. I literally cannot stand every part of my life.

Hey there, I quit drinking about 6 weeks ago. 3 weeks in, I noticed some issues. All the symptoms point to low blood sugar.

Does this ever balance out? My doctor is signaling that it isn't serious but the symptoms are super disruptive. When I eat, it balances temporarily but I am only now learning to be super intentional with what I am eating. It is stressful.

Does this go away?

Haven?t bought any alcohol for home consumption in several months. A bottle of whiskey I have still has whiskey in it.

Had 5 beers while out with friends 5 weeks ago, felt rotten about drinking too much.

Had 1 beer while out with a friend 2 weeks ago, felt great about not overdoing it!

Last weekend, took 3 shots of whiskey over 2 days, at home alone. Although you all will probably say that was a foolish decision, I am proud that I didn?t go overboard with it, as I have done countless times before

In my free time, I have been engaged with a new hobby, and have just not really felt like getting fucked up. Not sure how long my new hobby will be fascinating to me, but in the meantime I have had a couple of months reprieve from the bottle, and I?m actually feeling ok

I don?t know what?s going on with me. I drank almost every day, at least a 12 pack, but more commonly an 18 pack and whiskey. There were some times it was pretty bad.

I?ve been doing that for about a decade. I think a lot of my problem was wanting a cigarette and not liking smoking unless I was drinking, and I didn?t like drinking unless I was smoking, so they drove me to one another.

Anyway, over Christmas it dumped a foot of snow and was too cold outside to smoke so I cut back. I bought a vape and was able to just sit inside, and it didn?t give me the drinking urge I normally had.

Anyway, it?s been two weeks and I?ve maybe had five or six beers. If I wanted to I could just stop completely, I haven?t had a drink in a few days.

So I?d say I?m an alcoholic. I drink about every day and I like the person that I am when I?m buzzed. I don?t really like to get drunk but a steady buzz is perfect for me. I?m not unhappy I actually love my life and there is no real reason that I can think of as to why I am this way. I?m not depressed although I do suffer from anxiety but I?ve learned to basically control in over the years. Every now and the if it?s bad enough I will take a Xanax to ease my mind but I don?t take them regularly at all maybe once or twice a year. I?m just confused because everyone you see that has alcoholism is usually unhappy and what not but I?m not unhappy. I know it?s a problem though and if I don?t nip it in the bud it will be very bad. My mother and father are both alcoholics but my dad thank god has recovered and is a very strong minded person. I haven?t told anyone how bad my problem is because I?m embarrassed to be Frank and I don?t want others to see I am weak. Where do I start to quit?

Is managing drinking possible when you have a problem? I?ve been drinking everyday for the past couple years. I don?t drink hard liquor, and my drinking hasn?t really impacted my life much. I usually drink 8-10 beers a night, and feel like shit when I go a night without it.
I am only 20 years old and really don?t want to have to quit all together but I?ve noticed a dependancy, despite being a pretty good drunk for the most part, (not a big partier, and don?t do anything to crazy), I have a history of alcoholism in my family and don?t want to go down that path.
Is being sober the only answer? Or has anyone had success with cutting back and managing there drinking?
I know I need to do something but I love drinking and don?t really want to have to stop completely.
At least when I was drinking, if I made a joke about dead babies IN FRONT OF SOMEONE WHOSE BABY JUST DIED I?d just forget that shit. Now that memory gets to keep me up at night.

Hi, I'm hoping for some insight/advice. I'm (32f) currently separated from my partner (45m) of 13 years while I try to figure out whether I want to keep trying.

My partner is a regular heavy drinker. He drinks to the point of being wasted every Friday and Saturday night. Also uses cocaine every weekend (small ish amounts but very consistently every weekend). In the process of us becoming separated, I've brought up the issue of his substance use. My dad died when I was a child from an IV cocaine overdose, my mom was an addict, I have somehow narrowly avoided the same path. The cocaine is not the topic of my question but wanted to give context as to why I'm not ok with being around it.

When I brought up the fact I'm not ok with the cocaine, he said he understood but "you know I'm not going to stop drinking". He feels that getting wasted every Friday and Saturday night is not an issue, he can't possibly be an alcoholic, because he doesn't drink every day. He has long standing depression, anxiety, and a lack of self worth. I told him that I wished he didn't feel the need to get so wasted every weekend. That if he found a way to be comfortable with himself, perhaps by engaging with therapy, that he might no longer want to.

But it seems like he's not interested, and not willing to do this work. I'm at the stage where I'm thinking I want to start a family (I know .. after 13 years together... we've both avoided thinking too hard about our future together). I just can't have a kid with someone who insists on getting blackout drunk and doing blow every weekend night. And those evenings when he's drunk are the only times when he's open with me about his depression and self loathing. Another huge issue is that he doesn't remember these conversations the next day.

So... I guess my question is, am I crazy for viewing this drinking as an issue?? Am I crazy for asking him to consider therapy?? There's a lot of love there still... I see glimpses of the man he is outside of the depression and self identity issues and this is why I didn't run years ago.

I?m in tears, anxious, depressed and at the end of my rope. I had a terrible year last year and started drinking to cope around July/August. My father died so I drank more. My boyfriend left me so I drank even more. I drink about 7-8 shots of vodka a night. I can?t keep doing this. How do I stop? I?m scared to go cold Turkey as I?ve heard that can lead to death. I don?t wanna die. I?ve just been in so much emotional pain. It hurts so bad to be so alone.

Day 1 today. It's going better then expected considering my bender went on almost all day everyday last year. I weaned myself the past 3 days the best I could. I don't feel sick. But I am having the usual nightmares, insomnia, anxiety, and irritability. The thing that's bothering me the most is the irritability. I have a young child, and I date her father. Her father probably is setting me off the most. We never get along anyways, even before my long ass bender.. distancing myself isn't really an option. And advice to help myself out here??

I joined this group hoping to add something to it. My boyfriend of 8 years and father to our 6-year-old passed away in 2020 after being a high-functioning alcoholic for 20+ years. He was 44. His body just gave up....kidney failure, pneumonia, tracheotomy, coma....and it's all because of alcohol. My daughter is still processing everything. My heart breaks for her. I am slowly realizing the emotional abuse I suffered.....and working through it. Something I need to highlight here, though is that I am so thankful he is no longer suffering and dealing with YEARS of pain due to childhood trauma and ptsd after being in the army. Towards the end of his life, the alcoholism was in the forefront but now that he is gone I've learned so much about the disease and the reasons people suffer it. Alcoholics: I feel for you. Please get help...and SOON. Deal with your pain sooner than later, please. I know this is NOT EASY. Just believe in how crucial it is. You deserve BETTER.

(28m) I Feel infinitely better physically, focused on my health, eating right and exercising . Mental not so great, I?m in therapy regularly, have a good job, a good relationship, stability and hobbies but something really sucks and feels off 90% of the time, I?m always angry and almost act without thinking more now the I did when drinking like I?m almost getting off on my bad decisions, ( which are definitely waaaaayyy waaaaayyyyy less detrimental) but I?m bored and anxious, and I feel like an asshole in any social situations because I can?t function and just want to leave. My social skills are basically non existent. And the self loathing and hatred for myself continues to grow everyday. But here?s the catch I have no urge or want to drink. I?m just stuck in this god awful sober purgatory. I have friends (that drink) and I have sober friends( who I work out with and get coffee with ) but nothing goes beyond that. I have no life, and spend my time on this fucking hamster wheel of work,girlfriend,workout,hobbies. The repetition and stagnant boring stability is all I ever wanted when I was drunk and struggling to get sober and now I have it and I fucking despise it. I just get pissed off for no reason , I feel like I?ve lost my sense of purpose and happiness. I?m Grateful I?m sober but fuck man is this it? Anyone else struggle with the same things? I don?t work AA anymore, and have done meditation,journaling, and other recovery programs throughout my sobriety (inconsistently) but none of them really stuck and I just feel like an anxious empty asshole who?s sober. Please help.

This is my first post on here. I hope you?re all doing well in your journeys. I?m going through a bit of an experience at the moment and figured this would be the best place to come if I had any questions regarding anything.

So basically I?m 23 years old, 24 in a few days. For maybe the last 2 and a half years or so, I?ve been drinking pretty much every single night. This is not about AA (you're welcome) -- I believe in AA, but I'm talking about an earlier step. We can call this "step 0.5: You can quit in 5 days and also not seize at an AA meeting."

I'm talking about medical detox. Some vets of this sub probably think it's common knowledge, but if you're new to this like I was several months ago, it could save you a lot of uncomfortability. Once you learn how it works (or can work,) you may not be as hesitant to look into it.

This is how it has worked for me through a few relapses:

europlasticity is a process of modifying or changing the neural system. Neural pathways are the root or we can say the reason for our habits and URGE to drink in cases of people like us who are addicted to alcohol. So if we can modify these pathways which actually begins the Day we were born then we can control our urge without any giving up and being demoralised every time coz we couldn't control our urge. I HAVE TRIED IT MYSELF AND RESULTS HAVE BEEN OUTSTANDING. It will be myu pleasure if this Post helps anyone and i could be any use to you.

I'm sure it's all ego and fear but I need to find a way to stay sober and have other resources. Has anyone else felt this way after a relapse? Like everyone in AA is just annoying me lol so I know it's me, but I can't get past it at the moment.

Sometimes alcohol is the only thing that numbs it all
It?s no secret that I?m an alcoholic. From my friends to my doctors, etc. Then tonight it just hit me all over again. I?ve been stressed since the moment I could process memories as a child. From trauma, to being disowned for being LGBT, being homeless, mental health and hospitalizations, etc. A family history of alcohol the that and the lifelong trauma just hits it all. Sometimes just drink it clears me for a bit and makes me feel like none of that never happened and I?m just?here for once. But then it gets worse

I?ve lived with my roommate for a year and he knows my history and I struggle sometimes. But I?ve never let him see me get this bad. How do I go about getting a medical detox at home? I live with my folks and I also dont want them to know, and with school and work (both from home), I would rather just stay here.

Don't ever have alcohol in the house. Rule #2 Don't drink everyday. Rule #3 Only drink socially at a bar when your off from work. Rule #4 Look at yourself in the mirror everyday and say "I'm not an alcoholic, I could always control myself while drinking" it has to be done permanently like brushing your teeth. Rule #1 cannot work without Rule #4 and everything in between. The mind will slowly start convincing itself that you're not an alcoholic and you don't have a problem with alcohol. The bonus step is drinking lemon water everyday on an empty stomach. Look it up on YouTube, the health benefits are endless and it could potentially counter the negative effects of alcohol over time. Good luck and I hope this helps someone out there in need!

For the past year I?ve been spiraling. My relationship with alcohol has never been healthy. I could never just have one drink. But during the pandemic (like so many others) I became a daily heavy drinker. Hiding it from my family, daughter and husband (well at least I thought I did).

These past two months had become a nightmare. All I could think about was purchasing, planning and hiding my next drink. What?s more I felt like hell, physically and emotionally. Throwing up, stomach pains, foggy head, exhausted, my skin is wrecked and my hair had begun falling out. I found myself thinking I?d be better off dead.

I was hospitalized before thanksgiving for heart palpitations. Turns out my potassium had fallen extremely low (guess why?) I was released without being honest with my doctors. I?m sure they knew what had caused it. I got my metabolic panel back and just like anyone could have guessed? I had all the obvious indicators of alcoholism. But I still hit the bottle with the excuse ?after Christmas I?ll deal with this?.

I put on a brave face, but I was miserable the whole holiday. But there was always one little glimmer still left in me, that would say ?this isn?t it, there?s something else for you?. Thursday I was driving and seriously contemplated driving off the side of the road.

I wrote my husband a letter, I was still too ashamed of my addiction to say it out loud or to his face. And basically said I?ve been drowning in a dark place and I?m lost. Told him about the car incident and that it had scared the hell out of me. Told him I couldn?t be a good wife or mother until I got help.

Dumped all my booze and Went to the ER. Sat in the car for 30 minutes asking myself if I could really do this, and I did. I was completely honest and started medical detox. The staff, who I was scared would be judgmental, have been lovely and supportive. And so has my family.

Currently on Librium and Adivan along with fluids and plenty of vitamins. After detox I?ll be entering an intensive outpatient rehab program. I know it?s going to be one of the hardest things I do, but I?m so ready to be unburdened. Alcohol has felt like weights around my neck. Using alcohol to solve problems it was causing would have Killed me. But that?s what I was doing.

Just feeling relieved, lucky and privileged. I hope some others bite the bullet, be brave and go get help.

22F. Hi. I wanted to know if any of you had ever experienced with delirium tremens or at least strong alcoholic hallucinosis. What was your experience like and did you go to the hospital.

I wanted to share my story and have your opinion on it. Sorry if it's a little long. I'm just so traumatized.

I have been abusing alcohol for at least 2 years now with a 4/5 bottles every week. Two weeks ago I went absolutely nuts (I suffer from anxiety and alcohol was the only thing that helped me) and in the span of 5 days I drank 7 liters of vodka. I didn't sleep or eat anything during those 5 days. I also wanted to end it all so I did some stupid shit and took 5 painkillers. Then I stopped suddenly. My mom sent me to the hospital but I managed to escape. Got home. My hands were going crazy. I could not recognize anyone around me. I asked my mom her name multiple times. Which city we lived in. Stuff like that. Then I was rushed to the hospital again. They thought I was just being drunk and annoying so they locked me in a room for a few hours until my mom came to pick me up.

I got home, fell asleep for maybe 15 minutes, and when I woke up I was experiencing delirium tremens symptoms. I had the most terrifying auditory and visual hallucinations. I heard voices criticizing me, telling me my life is over. I was seeing things move in the room. I also felt like someone was touching my leg. It is truly the most terrifying thing someone could ever experience. You really think you are going insane. I heard the same song replaying in my head over and over again. When I clicked on a YouTube video, instead of the sound of the video, it was flashbacks of my mom's voice screaming at me, and when I paused the video it stopped, when I clicked again it continued. It was so precise. I went outside and the sounds of cars driving by were my mom's voice screaming at me.

Anyways I was about to literally die so I called the ambulance. I was rushed to the hospital and I explained all my symptoms. I thought they would help me. Instead, they locked me in a room with nothing but a bed and a straitjacket, which thankfully they did not put on me. They gave me nothing but a tiny glass of water. No medication. NOTHING. Now imagine you are already going insane, have been sleep-deprived for 5 days, stopped alcohol suddenly, you are hearing voices and you are being forcefully locked in a room with nothing but your thoughts. It was the most terrifying thing ever. The hallucinations became even stronger. I was sweating everywhere but I knew I had to act normal if I wanted to get out. So I just walked around the bed.

After being locked for 3 hours in this room, I was sent to a mental hospital which was what I asked for as I thought I was going insane. They gave me a valium which made me feel like my heart was going to stop. They also gave me vitamins. You really think a mental hospital is a place with just depressed people but it is something totally different and terrifying. On top of that, my hallucinations did not stop. I knew they would not do anything for me so I convinced them I was just too drunk and everything was back to normal now. I was sent back home after just a day. I immediately went to my family doctor and he is the one who prescribed me haldol to stop my hallucinations and other medication such as antidepressants and xanax. Imagine the hospital not helping you for 3 days but your family doctor does in 10 minutes. I took haldol for maybe 5 days.

While withdrawing from alcohol, I was careful to avoid caffeine since I noticed that it would worsen my jitters. Still jittery and reluctant to visit the doctor for benzodiazepines, I wished I had some type of downer to calm the jitters.

I remembered the bottle of bacopa that had purchased for anxiety. It is an herbal supplement and I recalled how tired it had made me. I took two capsules and noticed a dramatic improvement in my withdrawal symptoms. I no longer felt as jittery and if I recall correctly, my insomnia actually subsided.

Afterwards, I decided to look online to see if there was any information relating to bacopa and alcohol withdrawals. I found at least one scientific study, and several articles mentioning that bacopa has been found to help withdrawals, and is used in herbal medicine for that purpose.

I?m trying AA (no judgement about anyone who chooses not to). There have been a lot of great things but some things about AA bother me. I also posted in the AA sub, but I would like to hear opinions of people who aren?t going to automatically defend the program.

Here?s one thing that?s been bothering me?

We are told that if we don?t keep actively working the program, we are dangerously stepping closer and closer to a relapse. We have to keep working all 3 sides of the triangle, stay in the center, live step 10.

This is confirmed by many who have relapsed. They let their lives slip away from the program, relapsed, and are now back to continue doing the work, and to warn others what might happen if you ever stop.

What about the people who stopped ?doing the work? but didn?t relapse? We would never hear from them because, without a relapse, there?s nothing bringing them back to AA to tell the tale.

It?s circular logic that we are told we will relapse if we leave, because the only ones telling us about leaving are the ones who CAME BACK. What about people who slowly distanced over time and who?s lives are not in shambles as a result?

The only acknowledgement I have heard of this from people in AA is that, well, those people must not have been ?real alcoholics.? I do not think this is true at all. I think it?s a little dangerous to gate-keep the legitimacy of addiction? to say that if you?re a ?real? addict, you?re only hope is AA. And if you can survive without AA, you?re not a ?real? addict.

All this being said, I do not take relapse stories lightly. Im not turning up my nose to the advice about ?doing the work.? I am genuinely scared that if I stop doing the work, if I slip from the program, that I may relapse again. And it bothers me that AA has to instill this fear in people. What happened to, ?take what you need, leave the rest??

Does anyone see what I mean? What do you think of this?

Clearly these problems (financial, relationships, employment, general health) can?t be fixed while drinking but I have frequent dreadful realizations that I?m in deep trouble in a lot of ways, have to start dealing with it as best as I can without alcohol or drugs. It?s like I was sleepwalking through life, alcohol just makes it possible to not give a shit and let problems fester, I don?t know. I?m hoping many of you who found sobriety felt this way in the early days and that it?s not just me.

I used to get most of my calories from alcohol. I recently cut back to what I consider reasonable (2-3 shots and a beer, from 6 shots and a liter of wine or a sixer of beer)). However I am not noticing my hunger for food returning. I take vitamins and drink ensure so I know I am getting some calories. Any tips on firing the 'ol hunger? It's been a month at the lower rate

an i be an alcoholic/deal with those tendencies if i don't get to drink often? whenever there's alcohol around, i drink it (when i can get away with it without anyone knowing), but it's not often available as my dad isn't a big drinker. i also could drink right now, but he has one bottle of beer left, and he'd notice if i drank it. my question is though, is it wrong then to consider myself to have any issues with it?

in the past, i've gotten blackout drunk twice, and then close to it the other times, as i drank all i was able to. i kind of lose control of myself when it's available. the worst was when i was with a different relative, who does drink a lot, and was basically drunk for 5 days straight. i also think about drinking almost all the time. but i feel that, since i can control myself right now since i don't wanna get caught, i don't have any real issues with it.

I am an active dude Marine. That isn't how I started drinking, but that is definitely how I learned where to drink. My parents met at an AA meeting. 2 of my grandparents were alcoholics as well (coincidentally, they were both Marines). I love to drink. I can enjoy pretty much anything as long as there is booze involved. The job I have in the Marines one might consider high risk, but I am by no means a danger seeker. I've never had a ticket, I hate heights. But I drink and drive all the time. Never when I would consider myself "drunk" but I'll knock back 4 brews and hit the grocery store. My father was never around. My step dad is also a recovered alcoholic. He has a lot of regrets. So does Mom. And I would assume so does my actual father. I've never gotten in trouble for my drinking and I'm 28. But not from lack of trying. I don't feel withdraws when I'm not drinking. And with exception to one deployment and a few trips I have drank every day. My wife hates it. She has pretty much given up drinking at this point because she is a terrible drunk.

I?ve been in denial about my alcoholism and have been saying I have it under control. Through a very long lockdown I was drinking alone every night but didn?t acknowledge the harm as I thought I wasn?t hurting anyone. Now that life has opened back up again, there have already been numerous occasions where I have gotten too drunk and caused harm to myself and others. The final straw was when I got super drunk and hit on my sister?s partner. I had no recollection of the event and was mortified when she told me. Thankfully she was forgiving and more concerned about me but I am sick of needing people?s forgiveness. I have finally acknowledged that I cannot moderate and have an incredibly unhealthy relationship with alcohol and cannot have it in my life. Tbh I feel relieved, in the back of my mind (I?m a very avoidant person) I have been so scared about my drinking but now that I?ve honestly acknowledged the problem I feel hopeful.

My father is a massive alcoholic. Has been for years. He has massive nerve damage, brain damage, liver damage. He's stuck to his couch and totally unable to live a normal life. Recently, he's been having terrible delusions of grandeur.

He believes himself to be the most important person in the family. No one can live without him. Everyone owes him the world from his work as a trucker. Everyone loves him. He doesn't need help and his alcoholism has nothing to do with his numerous medical problems, etc.

Is this a common thing amongst alcoholics? I've seen some correlation between delusional disorder and substance abuse but he's always been a bit of a bragger. How do you guys get through this? What have you done to remedy your own delusions regarding addiction?

Can?t seem to find the delayed gratification ability it takes to just go to sleep instead of drinking. I?m drunk right now actually. I feel pretty mad at myself by the time I?m drunk and every minute until it?s aboit 6:00 pm and then boom I just feel like I?m ?getting the night started?. It?s very ritualistic. Time for 8 voodoo rangers and 2 movies. Gonna be a good night! Except that I know the effects and I know I?m 5 years away from it starting to show (I?m 24 btw) but I can?t seem to focus on the long term benefits of quitting. It also doesn?t help that I?m the farthest from denial. I know that I have a problem. I also (probably pretentiously) consider myself a highly intellectual person so I know what it takes to quit but I can?t hold that down for more than a couple days. I?m also afraid of rehab because I?ve tried to talk to the pros and even have a free over the phone therapist but because I?m so aware of the facts I feel as though their not going to tell me anything I don?t already know

Highly functioning one here. I don?t believe I?m ruining my life by drinking. I Just want to take a nice long break for my mental/physical health. I?m anywhere from 4 beers to 7 vodka clubs at night before bed (The latter more than not). (31/M). Been doing this for years now. I have taken stretches of like 4 days off. And the most I?ve had was trouble sleeping and cold sweats. Heart palpitations maybe. What are some of your experiences?

A bit of context my dad is a heavy binge drinker. He doesn?t really drink often anymore but when he does there?s a 50/50 chance that he?ll go on a week long bender.

So far, it?s been 6 days of 24/7 drinking and I?m trying to help him out. We tried sending him to a detox center a while back and it worked but left us with a $10,000 medical bill (which was forgiven but wtf - what a scam). I noticed that he started trembling a bit and was wondering whether this is common or whether its a sign that he needs professional care (trying to exhaust every option before this because his insurance doesn?t cover substance abuse). Also, I?m wondering if he?s too far gone to help him taper off and if not, what a good strategy is to use for doing so. We will surely have a conversation about therapy, abstinence, and AA after he recovers from this bender though.

I don't drink that often, but when at parties or when I'm going out to a pub I do often drink to much. Almost every party i have some degree of memory loss and sometimes I act improperly.

Basically im asking you if I should be worried for my future, alot of my relatives have had problems with drink and I've heard such things can have an impact. I'm 19 and started drinking at 16 if that matters.

Is my current situation bad or does it seem like it could grow into something worse? Thanks for any answers and happy new year!

Are there definite links between long term alcoholism and long term depression? Or is that just said because alcohol is technically a depressant? I've struggled with anxiety and depression most of my life, but I've also been drinking since I was a teenager. I've taken some sober stints in my life, but they never helped my depression, even in combination with diet and exercise.

Is there a certain amount of time to quit until depression fades?

My girlfriend?s ex husband had been alcohol dependent for some time. We have been trying so hard to get him to recognise his problem and seek help but on Christmas Eve we saw him for the first time in 3 weeks and his physical decline was so shocking to see. We decided to ignore his requests for privacy and checked on him a few days ago. We broke into his home and found him collapsed on the floor. After calling for an ambulance we were informed to sit him up and wait for their arrival. He was able to respond to me but was very confused and it was near impossible to understand what he was trying to say. Once the paramedics arrived they started to assess him. They asked me to lie him down but on doing so, his heart stopped beating. He was lifted by the fire brigade from the roof, placed in an induced coma and is currently on a ventilator. I guess my question might be naively optimistic but should he come through this will the time unconscious count as detox? Could this be a good opportunity to continue recovery from this point? I really don?t know what the realistic outcome to this is. Anyone here had anything similar with a loved one?

My mum (69) has recently admitted to me (37f) she has a drinking problem and needs help. I didn?t realise until recently how bad it was.

She doesn?t want to go to AA meetings, and I want to do everything I can to support her and help her with this. I worry about her trying to go cold turkey on her own - as I?ve heard this can be really dangerous in heavy drinkers.

Has anyone gone through this with an older parent? Any help or advice appreciated.

I made it one whole year without alcohol!!!! I knew quitting drinking was going to be good for me but never in my wildest dreams did I imagine just how good life could be without alcohol!! Best decision I ever made! And the pride I feel today is unbelievable!! Just wanted to share my special day with all you amazing people because I have gainded alot of tools and insight from y'all.

I am looking for advice on how my wife and I should deal with this.

Our daughter is 22 and has twin 18-month old boys. We have taken over care for them but she still has legal custody.

We just feel bent over a barrel in terms of not enabling her addiction. If we cut off financial support, she?s shown us that she will prioritize drinking and smoking over proper care of the boys.

But if we take on the responsibility, she has the time/money/freedom of responsibility to just go on a bender every day.

The added difficulty is that she?s still in the process of finalizing custody with the twins? ?father?, (I use quotation marks because he?s had very little involvement and is a drug dealer and drug abuser). Our concern is that letting it get to a point where Child Services is involved will give him an opportunity to try and get custody. Not to mention that our daughter isn?t so far gone in her addiction that she couldn?t pull herself together long enough to convince Child Services she?s competent and then cut us off completely.

She?s on a wait list for a detox program, and says she wants to go to a woman?s rehab clinic after that. But she?s talked the talk before and has a history of failing to go through with things.

I am just wondering if there?s a good way to deal with this situation and get her the help and support she needs while at the same time keeping the boys safe, and giving us the sense of security that she can?t just ?feel good at the time? and come and take the boys back then we get a call later that night where she?s drunk and we need to go back and get the boys.

I?m looking for a plan to put in place that not only holds him accountable but keeps me safe and informed?

This is the last challenge of the year folks. Stay strong! No shame in sitting this one out, tagging along with your not sober friends, find support if you need it or whatever. I still think about drinking every day but life truly is so much better without it. Thank you to everybody here, whether you?re 10 years sober, 10 days sober or just thinking about sobriety. you?re fucking awesome and I?m so happy to be abreast you all while push past all the awfulness.

This past month has not been good for my drinking. I live alone and my background in the restaurant industry hasn?t helped me with steady income for 2 years now. This pain is unbearable. I don?t know what to do now but peace out. Hope you guys fair better than me I wish I had better words for you but I?m in agony. Don?t sink as low as me.

I went through a bad breakup 2 years ago. I?m currently clearing out my apartment of their stuff. Blocked them just recently.

I looked at myself in the mirror and notice how much I?ve aged in these past 2 years. I used to take care of my skin so well. Probably been getting blackout drunk at least 4 times a week.

Idk just noticed and wanted to vent. I have about a 1/3 of a bottle of whiskey left but why bother? I?ll probably have to get more anyways if I wanna get drunk.

There?s nothing else to do though. I?ve been doing laundry all day but there?s nothing left to fold. I can?t focus on a movie. My bathroom and bedroom is totally clean and I have nothing to distract myself from how lonely I am.

I'm a bit disappointed in a way, I gained some weight in the past few months, probably from drinking too much beer, I recently told myself I should really stop drinking, I'm 3weeks in, I thought I would have lost weight and feel better because of it but my weight hasn't changed at all, and its not as if I'm eating McDonald's everyday or anything.

It has been one year today! Now let me be clear. It has been a year since my last blackout. A year since I kicked my family out the house because I didn't want them to se me destroy it. A year since tried to destroy my wife's self-esteem. A year since since she found out she wasn't the only one.....a year. The only advice I can give is if you don't believe in a higher power, believe in LOVE. Yall take it easy.

She says she only needs therapy- not AA or other support groups.

Should I believe her? I?m so fucking angry. I hate this. She is an amazing person but the alcohol is a beast.

I work pretty much every day (at home), seven days a week. Decided to allow myself some alcohol during the holiday season and here are my observations regarding my productivity:

Without alcohol: I work assiduously through my tasks. It's rather mundane and uninteresting, but I get through them in a timely manner.

With alcohol: Things seem rather less mundane and uninteresting under the influence of alcohol, yet I find myself getting through them in a sluggish and inefficient manner, oftentimes getting distracted and delayed/procrastinative.

I would say, overall, my productivity is about the same with, or without, alcohol. Make of that what you will. At least without alcohol, I find myself with some extra time to indulge/do other tasks non-work related, whereas with alcohol, almost everything is a blur.

this year has been hell for me. I?ve been drinking excessively for 4 months now. About 7 shots of vodka a night. I want to stop because I don?t want to die, but I can?t sleep without it and the emotional pain of what?s happened this year is just too much to face anymore.

So i don't drink alot but since im off work till the next week ive been drinking everyday for 2 weeks and only 2-3 drinks a day however im getting very anxious if i don't have a glass as well as bouts of depression. Im thinking about tapering down until i feel better but very unsure if this is wise. Ive been kinda on edge from not drinking and kinda being a b word

I know, there?s lots of questions about this but I?m still not sure. Last year I used to drink one bottle of wine every week. It was nice and fun to loosen up a bit sometimes. This year a lot of bad shit happened around me and I felt I was losing it. One bottle became two and now I drink something every day. It?s not that much, like 3-4 glass of wine per day but I really feel like I couldn?t live without it. I start to feel nervous if I realize that we ran out of wine at home. Sometimes I feel like wine just doesn?t do the trick anymore and I want to drink something stronger but I know if I start drinking stronger drinks daily, then there?s no stopping. Sometimes alcohol doesn?t make me happy and less anxious anymore, I often get panic attacks after drinking. I still can?t stop though. Is this a sign to quit? Or that 3-4 glass/day isn?t that unhealthy? I have BPD by the way, I tend to get addicted to things.

He has a deep hatred for my mother even though she has tried her utmost best to support him and he blames her for everything. When he drinks he becomes an intolerable asshole and no one can stop him. He went to rehab but didn?t stay sober and spends his nights drinking with his ?friends? that seem to have the combined intelligence of a four-year-old. I live abroad but have come back to visit for the holidays. I can see that the situation has not improved at all since I left and I don?t know how to be useful. I love him and he has a good heart but he his hurting everyone who actually care about him. Please help.

I?ve been drinking way too much for the last six months. I?ve stuck to beers with around 4-5.5%, and for the last month I?ve drank about a six-pack or eight a day (2L+). As I?m sure many others do I decided to break it off for the new year. I?ve had sober days where I haven?t noticed a lot of side effects, and this might be a ridiculous thing to ask, but just trying to cover all bases.

So my bestie a couple of years ago realised they were an alcoholic. They got sober and made lots of changes and started to lose weight as well. The last year has been a challenge for them and the drinking has become a more regular thing again. I want to get some advice on how i can be there to help. Any advice will be gratefully received. We are in the uk and in my area there is little available apart from AA which isn't their cup of tea or full on rehab.

Last drink was the 19th, was a 8-10 beers 6 nights a week. The first week, I was really productive, cleaned my whole depressive apartment, walked to work and felt great. Now in the 2nd week, I'm having trouble sleeping, with my apartment clean I feel like I have nothing to do, every night my mind is just constantly trying to convince me to go to the store. I want that week 1 feeling back, or at least not this feeling anymore.

Feels so good! I?m shocked! My work performance is better, I sleep better, I honestly NEVER imagined I could pull this off. I would like to help others at some point but I?m still in the early days of sobriety. After 7 day detox with 3 days on Ativan I was fine. I went home and opted out of rehab due to my work responsibilities. I have tried 12 step groups and it just is not for me. Not sure why but I feel like I do not want to rehash the drunk days. I wonder what another option would be besides going to the gym. My only problem I guess now that o don?t drink I have zero social skills.

After 5 years of intensive drinking and being a slave to the bottle, I?ve been free for one week. Withdrawals weren?t as bad as I intended (thank goodness). That?s what kept me from getting sober for so long. I was terrified of the withdrawals. I made it through and today I?m feeling better than I have in awhile albeit a little moody still. Still taking vitamins, still drinking water. Will probably start working out soon. I want to be healthy again. Anyone who?s scared of the process please seek help. If you?re like me and detox at home take extreme caution and have someone available to assist you if need be.

For som context my fathr and my maternal grandfather was and are alcoholics. They have had alot of prpblems with it for many years. I just turned 18 and have started going to home parties and to pubs and clubs.

I find that almost everytime i drink i cant stop myself from drinking more. I dont feel a need to drink and i keep drinking to weekends. But as soon as i get a couple of drinks in me i feel this bruning urge to drink more. I can feel that i shloudnt drink more but i keep drinking anyway. I often get blackout drunk (although ive never passed out) and the day after im deppressed as shit.

I know my problem isnt nearly as bad as it could be but i just want some help to not fall in the same hole my father did.

Sweating, shaking, dry heaving. Woke up 5am just now but went down around 12:30. Last time it was like this was a couple months ago accompanied as well by early signs of psychosis/delirium tremens, including auditory hallucinations and seeing shadow figures.

All I had left were four 9% ciders and half a bottle of brandy, and not even that amount was enough to fight off withdrawal for the morning.

I?m terrified and I?m just so tired, man I want this to be the last time. All I have to do is not go get drunk with my whole paycheck when I get this next one.

I wanna go to the hospital right now because I?m in serious agony, but I?m out of money and have to work this week because I?m short a coworker due to a skiing accident. I work in a bar too.

So im a social drinker , dont drink everyday or after work but lets say the weekend rolls around and im drinking with friend i have a real problem stopping and i guess it affecting my relationships with people, anyone have a better way of getting past this?

Right now my mom is trying to quit, shes 1 day in and shes shaking, irritable, and dizzy. What are some things i can do to help her right now? I cant stand seeing her like this, and im the only one that can help her right now so i have nobody else to go to.

I know I know it's never just a 1 time thing, it's a slippery slope. But I'm over a year sober I feel mentally stronger in that aspect,, my goal was stay sober a year because my hallucinations were telling me... Today seems different. I know I can do just this once, definitely planning going to A.A meetings again though. I don't know just had to share my current dilemma.

Everywhere I look all the resources I find about drinking talk about numbing yourself, and I simply don't relate to that. I feel numb when I'm sober. When I drink I can feel anger at people that have wronged me who otherwise I'd let walk over me, I drink because food tastes better when drunk so I struggle to eat proper when sober, I drink because it makes me love people who deserve love and I hate how distant I otherwise feel. Sadly I struggle to seek help about my emotional issues without having a few drinks first, because I can't talk about my issues otherwise.

I don't think I'm unique, so surely there is something out there that acknowledges this seemingly different attitude to drink that from my point of view is overlooked.

I?ve followed this page for months, debating on whether or not I have a problem, usually while drunk. I?m typing this sitting at a barstool looking at a full beer I ordered 20 mins ago. Well I?ve been off the devils cum for about 13 days now. I had left my town to go to my hometown for some reflection and to gather myself up. My wife told me the details of what she saw and what I was doing at the time I was blacked out (the details are bad and I understand why I traumatized her). she?s asking for me back and wants to a trial run of trying to get back some normalcy. (We know it?s not that easy). This is my ONE chance to get my shit together and show her that I?m willing and and determined to fix us. I know I got it and it?s disappointing to me that this had to happen for me to smarten up and change. to those who are going thru some shit, pick yourself up and keep trying. I?m an angry drunk and I truly hate myself for it, alcohol makes my personality do a complete 180. I wish I could have a healthy relationship with alcohol. I?m never usually like this.

i?ve been drinking a minimum of 60 ounces of 45% liqour and a 30 pack of beer a week although normally a lot more frequently twice that, i?m 19 although i?ve been drinking like this amount since 16. it never affected my work and was never late or missed a day. it?s hasn?t affected family life and never believed it affected my social life until i sit hwre bottle in hand realizing i have no one left, i?ve never been an angry or aggressive drunk, just overly honest and talkative and i guess that put me in a position of decline over the years to the point i no longer have anyone i could call a friend. this is mostly just a vent, nowhere else to convey this. but i can honestly say now consider myself an alcoholic and realize it?s affected my life negatively. hoping this gives me the motivation to change things this time

I'm 16 and I drink every evening. I'm rarly happy without drinking and that's why i get drunk so often. I failed exams because I was drunk. I talked about it with many people but I don't want to stop. And that's why i hate myself.

He mentioned this scoring was because he drank a lot the day before, and hadn?t brushed his teeth (it was like 9pm the next day). Your doctor hasn't heard of it. Your rehab didn't teach you about it. AA won't let people openly discuss it.

Why do you suppose? It's evidence based, clinically proven.

Like most people with this medical condition (AUD) you probably haven't been told about short-term, as-needed, naltrexone and the method of taking it before drinking to help your brain taper down to any level you want (alcohol-free being the healthiest goal). Cravings and obsessive thoughts for alcohol slowly disappear. The brain rewires and heals itself. This method can work for 3 out of 4 people that can stick to the one rule method for 4-12 months. You use less and less naltrexone as the months pass.

I don't get physical hangovers, however I get psychical hangovers. So, I've been drinking heavily (12pks) at least once a week for months now, the past couple of months, it's been 2x, sometimes 3x a week (usually finishing the whole case, sometimes more than a case, blacking out, etc) and I had an epiphany over the weekend that I'm using alcohol as an unhealthy coping mechanism. I?ve been a functioning alcoholic for over 10 years. My weight has gone up significantly, and so has my tolerance. My husband is fed up with my drinking and gave me an ultimatum.

I quit drinking cold turkey, and am on day 2. All morning long, my heart has been racing, and my hands have a mild tremor. I have the worst anxiety and feel like I am losing my mind. I still have an appetite, and have not been nauseous or vomiting.

I?m not sure if it is all in my head, or what. But as the day progressed, I felt worse and worse and thought I was going to have a panic attack. I was able to make Christmas breakfast for my kids and watch them open their presents.

But when we were on our way to my in-laws, I had us stop at a drugstore to get a last minute gift for my father in law. My husband and kids stayed in the car.. I then also bought a few tiny boxes of wine and shoved them in my purse.

I drank them all, and almost immediately felt better and no longer felt as crappy as I did earlier. I did not get drunk at all, and had a mild buzz that wore off fast. I of course told no one, and am terrified. My husband said that if I drink without telling him, he will be furious. But then, when this happens he gets mad at me: so naturally I kept this in secrecy.

I don?t want to drink anymore, but do not have the time nor the means to do inpatient detox. I have to work and take care of my kids. I don?t have any family to help out, and my in-laws hate me as it is.

How do I go about doing an at home detox? When I tried it in the past, I was always yelled at and told to go to the hospital. This is not an option for me, and I am so lost and have no direction.

anyway, the gist is I constantly feel lonely and drinking is how i?m dealing with that. I was on another 5 day bender, and tried to take my dog to the dog park at 9am. I brought a bottle of wine with me in my car to try to drink as much as I could before- god forbid- I had to be without alcohol at the dog park for 45 mins. I was so drunk I couldn?t even get out of the car and called my best friend because I needed help and needed to surrender and be done. She shared with me today, that when she picked me up I didn?t even recognize her. I had a glaze over my eyes and didn?t look like me. I had wine stains all over my shirt and my car. My car had empty wine bottles all over and smelled like throw up. She somehow got me and my dog in her car, and took me home and just let me sleep all day.

I wanted to die the next day. Truly, wanted to not be alive. I could not handle the pain anymore. I just tried to get through the day sober. I started putting together days, with 2 AA meetings a day.

Personal story time? I went to the hospital for alcohol withdrawal yesterday (first time). The first doctor just told me to quit (super helpful, thanks!) and there was nothing he could do. And accused me of lying.

The second doctor came in and told me they they?re seeing SO MUCH of this because of the stress the last few years. She said ?you?re not alone. I will help you? and gave me some meds in my IV to stop shaking and then wrote me a Rx to help at home. I sobbed because I was so grateful.

Like, what the actual fuck.

For contest, I?m a young mother of two with an advanced degree who has NEVER sought help of this magnitude before.

I have been avoiding bars since quitting. But I couldn't this weekend. I was out of town for an event and our leader decided we would all meet at the hotel bar to discuss our upcoming program. I didn't want to go, but if I didn't I would be missing out on important strategy planning of a project we have coming up. So, I had fear of missing out....but not of fun or companionship. Fear of missing vital information to this project we are doing.

So I went. And when the waitress came, I refused to even acknowledge her at first. Rude. But I was afraid I would order something I didn't want to if I did. I finally told her I didn't want anything and got an very awkward look from her. Everyone else ordered alcoholic beverages. And consumed them. In front of me. And it was torture. I was so distracted that I didn't even pay attention to what was said.

When there was finally a pause in the action, I excused myself from the table. But instead of leaving like I knew I should have, I went to the bar. While I was at the bar, everyone was ordering their second round. I got the attention of the bartender. She came over to take my order and......I asked her if she could make me a virgin margarita on the rocks. And she did. And that is what I returned to the table with. And then I ordered a second one from the waitress when she came around again about a half hour later.

And it worked. And I did it. I was very, very tempted to not include the "virgin" part of my order. But I did. And I didn't end up have 5-6 regular ones. And I didn't embarrass myself in front of everyone. And I didn't wake up with a hangover forcing me to drag ass all day. I actually did. I feel good about it. I wanted to share. But I also don't ever want to feel that level of temptation again. It is the most I have had since starting this journey this time around.

I?m a big fan of interesting dates, so I was excited when I realized my one year would fall on 2/2/22.

I feel like I don?t deserve to celebrate one year because I wasn?t a ?problem drinker? and I didn?t hit a rock bottom. In fact I?ve retyped and deleted this post a few times. I didn?t make not drinking a public thing, I just casually declined opportunities, so it?s not like extended people in my life are aware I wasn?t drinking, but I?m still proud of doing what I set out to do, one day at a time and want to be able to celebrate with someone.

With a significant number of alcoholics in my family, I could see how easily it could become a problem for me. I was counting the days a week I was drinking, tracking how many drinks I had to make sure it wasn?t too many, but excited about the next one. When I was younger, I blacked out every time I drank and I didn?t realize that wasn?t what everyone did.

I'm 32, for the first time in over ten years I'm 16 hours sober and I feel like death. I'm shaking and cold and puking and I don't know if I can do this.

I don't know what I want from this post, I got really good at hiding it, so I've been about to remain fairly lubricated for a decade and I'm just realizing I don't know how to do anything without alcohol. Like, anything. And it feels gross to burden people with this information now.

I'm just rambling at 6am cause I can't sleep. Is it normal to dream about booze?

Met with my GI specilists for the first time today it turned out okay. I was diagnosed 2 weeks ago and made a follow up appointment with his office that was set for this morning. I was nervous because he had some not so great google reviews but I found the office staff and the doctor himself perfectly fine which is always good. He asked me if I had been drinking since being released I let him know not a single drop. Had 13 years, went back to drinking during the pandemic. I?m ashamed and can?t tell anyone how bad it?s gotten. I?m tired of blacking out, hiding bottles, and abusing my body and mind.

Today I?m proudly celebrating one year alcohol-free. I could NOT have done it without this sub. binge drinker here.

It's been 9 days since I've had a drink. I promised myself I would go a month without touching any alcohol to assess how/if I can handle it.

It was very easy to abstain during the week but once it hit Friday the cravings got super intense. I noticed that I was incredibly bored and agitated. I kept thinking about how much a glass of wine would help to enhance whatever I was doing (like cooking for example).

I made sure to stay very busy. I'm very lucky and grateful for my boyfriend who was incredibly helpful and supportive.

I?ve always been a runner. As I got into my 40s I found myself aching more after runs, feeling worse the next day, and just not having the same energy as I did when I was younger. Then in summer of 2020 I had a hip injury caused by many years of running. Combined with the pandemic, well my drinking really ramped up. After recovering from hip injury, I tried running again, but the hip was alway sore, legs felt worse, and I figured it was time to hang up the running shoes.

Fast forward to early this month (last drink on Nov 13th of 2021), I?m feeling more energetic than I have in years, so I start doing some short runs on the treadmill. I notice I can do 2 miles of running plus some waking without hip pain, and, amazing to me, my legs feel good and the next day I feel like I can do more. Then one day I feel great, and I tell myself I think I can run 5 miles?.so 45 minutes later, I?m done with the 5 miles! I figured I would be hurting the next day (yesterday) and I woke up and my legs barely hurt at all. Another 3 yesterday and 4 today and I feel like my old self!

Now this might not be tied to not drinking, it I sure think it is. I?m not dehydrated from drinking, my body can use it?s energy on healing muscles from working out and not ridding itself of toxins, I?m sleeping better which obviously helps with recovery, I?m not having the drinking shits, so my body is keeping the nutrients it needs, and best of all, my hip doesn?t hurt nearly as much! It?s amazing what the body can do when not drinking!

TL:DR: quit drinking, able to run again like I did in my 20s/30s

Today marks 6 months sober. No beer, no shots, no wine, no hangover, no morning after regret. It's been a very challenging 6 months, but worth it. So many reasons to give in and have 'just one'. But here I am. Thank you, community. It feels different this time. I don't hate my sobriety. I am starting to feel that I control my life. That I run this ship.

I feel pretty stupid for deciding to drink again. Being sober was going really well. I was sleeping well, walking a lot of steps daily, eating well, keeping up with all my responsibilities and getting out for hikes on the weekend.
Then there was a death in my family. My online course felt too overwhelming to keep up with. I started to fall out of my good routines.

Then I drank 1 night. I tried to resist. My partner and I had both admitted we were thinking about it then he went and bought some. I sat for a couple hours, glass of wine already poured but trying to resist, knowing I didn?t want to throw away my progress and start the cycle.

Caved. Told myself it wouldn?t happen again. Blackout, don?t remember going to bed. The next morning I felt so crappy. Tried to power through but drank again ?to take the edge off?. Blacked out again. Argued with my partner. Don?t remember going to sleep again. Attempted to go for a walk and do some chores the next day but still felt so off. Anxious, even my vision felt weird, my entire body felt weird. So we drank again. Not as much as the previous nights. It didn?t really make me feel any better but I do remember going to bed.

This has to come to an end now. It?s so easy to fall back into the cycle of feel crappy, drink, feel crappy from drinking, drink again. It feels like life on hard mode. Basic responsibilities feel so so difficult. Just trying to keep my plants and fish alive and not let my home turn into a total wreck feels so hard but it is the bare minimum. All I want to do is curl up in bed but the anxiety is so bad there?s no way I can sleep the day away.

So today I will shower. I will go for a walk. Try to read for my class. But my main goal, the very most important, is to not drink today, no matter how uncomfortable it is.

Binge watching Love Is Blind (it's okay to judge) and it's amazing how much liquor they shove down the contestants throats. There's obviously some sponsorships (Jack Daniels shots anyone?) but it's crazy how there is not one scene where they aren't drinking. I see myself in these women and men grabbing their wine glass any time they leave a room.

I don't think they would let a sober person on this show. I'm convinced reality TV is 95% alcohol and 5% sundresses.

I'm lucky enough to be able to dedicate this time to resting. Tapering the valium with each day, taking thiamine etc and drinking loads of water.

I had a call from the addiction clinic and the 9 week intensive will start in a few weeks. I'll be detoxed by then plus will have had some ENT day surgery I've been sorely needing.

Here's to starting a new season (autumn here) with a life reset.

Hi Been a heavy drinker for 20 years. I have two teen boys (13 and 15), with shared custody. In the past two years, with the pandemic, working from home, the isolation... my drinking picked up and they started being more and more aware. It made them.mad and I am trying to improve our relationship. It is a balancing act between talking and also giving them their time. Any suggestion or experience you can share would be welcome!

This is the longest I?ve gone in over a year. Over the last 4 months, I went through a breakup, helped my mom while she recovered from cancer treatment, and had the stress of running my own company with no days off. My life kept getting worse, and I knew drinking would only make things worse. I quit drinking and smoking weed cold-turkey on Dec 15 2021 and I?m so proud of how far I?ve come since then.

In the last 69 days.. I?ve gotten back to working out, improved my relationships, reduced my anxiety, cleared up my skin, and feel a lot healthier inside and out.

In the middle of paws and all I can do is vent on here

Decided to go to the liquor store for a beer and a handle and 24 hours later here I am.

My nose is broken and swollen , I?m missing a toe nail and I?m not even sure how. I?m too shaky to do anything but stare at a stupid stuffed turtle I got for my now ex for valentines.

The one person in the world I could really talk to and now in no uncertain terms wants nothing to do with me. I wish she would have yelled at me or punched me or anything other than cry. She tried so hard to help me and this is how my sorry ass says thanks.

One fucking slip up and basically anything that was going good in my life went straight down the shitter.

Loneliest I?ve ever felt in my life. I don?t even know where to start. This was day 55 and I just said fuck it because quitting drinking has become this huge rift. It wasn?t a huge lapse, but it?s why I did it that?s killing me. Because we don?t get along without it. Just a glass to show I?m not rigid, right?

And I have no friends without it. Our social lives are completely intertwined. Our professional lives are intertwined. I can?t maintain the status quo of my life without this component and it?s making me furious and so very, very resentful.

I feel as though I cannot win. This is hopeless. All I want is a better life where I?m in complete control of my emotions, my decisions and my behavior. And this is being taken as some sort of act of war.

I need to quit drinking. I've been a heavy drinker for 10 years, so I'm probably at a high risk for DT's and dying from quitting cold turkey... but I also know that I don't have the self control to slowly wean off.

I have come to terms with the fact that I can never be a "casual drinker." Even if I have the best intentions to stop at three beers, once I start, I cannot stop. It's been that way when I started in my early 20's to curb my social anxiety (the false sense that I'm more fun/outgoing when I'm drunk, when in reality, I just make an ass of myself. The only difference between then and now is that I'm more self-aware of my actions the morning after lol). I'm not sure what to do from here, but I'm sick and tired of being sick and tired, so to speak. I don't want to be an active alcoholic anymore.

Can anyone share their experiences with quitting cold turkey, going through withdrawals, etc? I know I can Google the information, but it helps to hear from real life experiences to know what to expect as I close this chapter in my life. And, Google convinced me that I will die from withdrawal, which just adds to my anxiety about quitting. I don't want to die...
